story:
The Campaign and the Impact

India is moving towards social transformation and the importance of women equality is rising. There is a growing need to educate women especially the younger generation that is about to enter the working environment. We all know the famous adage if we empower a woman, the whole village is empowered.

The main challenge that women face, particularly those in semi-rural and rural regions, include:

  • Inequality inherent mainly where traditional societies prevail
  • Lack of life skills
  • No knowledge of personal finance skills as money is handled by the men
  • Minimum control over life decisions

Women who are educated on personal finances and life skills can achieve success and independence they previously never thought was possible. Financial knowledge can be the most powerful resource a woman can have. Our Life & Money workshops, as seen with previous women participants, lead women to:

  • Attain more knowledge
  • Build confidence
  • Make better decisions
  • Change financial behaviour by smart spending, saving and investing
  • Achieve personal and financial goals

Click here to view a video snippet and feedback from a workshop conducted for women college students. (video section begins after 40 seconds)

When more women have more financial education, it will literally lead to a more successful future for all people of India. 

Our aim is to conduct Life & Money workshops for the hundreds and thousands of women across semi-rural and rural districts in India over a period of time. We want to begin this project by empowering 1000 women in Kanchipuram (a semi-rural district in India) with financial freedom. We plan to conduct these workshops in women colleges.

Meg Jay, author of 'The Defining Decade: Why Your 20s Matter and How to Make the Most of Them', says "20s is one of the simplest, yet most transformative, things you can do for work, for love, for your happiness, maybe even for the world." We want women in their youth to empower their 20s with the right financial and life decisions.


What We Need & What You Get

We require funds for the entire project. Funds will be allocated as follows:

  • 38% towards workshop related, materials, stationary and printing costs
  • 26% towards travel related and related administration costs for business development
  • 17% towards marketing communication campaigns and materials to reach out to participants
  • 19% towards human resource costs

Here is our budget (in Indian Rupees): 

You will earn the satisfaction of helping college going women students, who predominantly represent the lower income group, by giving them access to our workshop program. In return, as an appreciation and gratitude for helping us out on the project, we will be offering several perks. Please do see the perks section of this campaign for details.

Additional funds will go towards reaching out to additional participants in Kanchipuram district.


Risks & Challenges 

College timings as well as scheduled timetables may create a concern with regards to scheduling workshops and completing the project in time. We have identified four colleges in Kanchipuram region to reduce the risk. With prior experience of approaching corporations to conduct employee assistance programs and investor education programs, we aim to apply our learnings of marketing towards our program for women colleges.


Other Ways You Can Help

We'd really appreciate if you can spread the word and share our campaign details with friends and family members.

Thank you in advance. Please do check the updates section for future updates.


About Us

Life & Money is a division of Accretus Solutions India LLP. Accretus was incorporated in 2010 as an LLP and currently the two co-founders - Partha Iyengar and Prajakta Shidhore each own 50% stake in the company. Until date, it has been self-funded. At Life & Money, our 3E process of Engage, Empower and Energize through our experiential learning and outcome driven workshops help participants lead a healthy, wealthy and happy life. So far, we have reached out to over 1600 millennials across India by delivering workshops for college students, consumers in their 20s age group and millennial employees across corporations in India. 

About Partha: Partha has total 27 years work experience spanning sales, advertising and financial services. Last 15 years in financial services helping individuals achieve their personal and financial goals.

story: My name is Kevin,I am an outdoor person.The fancy is an item me and my mother thought of while sitting outside in the sun in Tucson Az. It will be an item that blocks the shade while misting you with water. I'm currently in the process of having an engineer build my design with 3d cad equipment. From there I will build my first prototype, I will then look for a manufacturing company to produce the productInventor of the fancy : https://youtu.be/S7RUkON1Zl4.

story:
“She could never go back and make some of the details pretty. All she could do was move forward and make the whole beautiful.”―Terri St. Cloud 


Hello! I’m Kim Roxburgh, founder of Hope Rises−a nonprofit organization assisting women coming out of prison and jail. For the last two years I've been on an exciting journey with a team of determined, compassionate people to see how Hope Rises can best fill a massive gap in services for women transitioning back into our downtown Little Rock community. This journey has taken us into the county jail, prison, halfway houses, and numerous meetings with community members, nonprofit leaders, and local and state government officials. In the beginning, our organization offered only day-program services to recently released women in the Pulaski County Detention Facility and at local halfway houses. However, it became clear that the need for safe housing that provided treatment and structure was desperately needed. Unfortunately, halfway houses have experienced a number of problems that indicate the industry is in need of systemic improvements. 

A house is shelter and a basic need. Providing treatment and support in addition to safe housing is exactly what research tells us is needed to reduce the risk of re-incarceration.

And so, the Hope Rises Wellness and Recovery House idea was formed.

Our correctional system offers very little in terms of rehabilitation. For this reason, women need more than “halfway” in terms of housing and treatment when returning to the community.

The first six months to one year following the release from incarceration is a critical time for women. It can be difficult to not resort back to the “old way of life” when faced with, what seems like, insurmountable obstacles of gaining full-time employment, housing, dealing with untreated physical and mental health issues, reuniting with family, and maintaining sobriety. Often the women we serve do not have the money to pay for accommodations up front. Hope Rises will give them a "working grace period" while they obtain full-time employment, receive treatment services, and obtain necessary documents. This grace period will keep them out of the shelters and off the streets.

We support each woman in her own unique journey toward transformation. The Hope Rises Wellness and Recovery House will be"more than halfway" by providing:

Our 6-month program is designed to guide women through numerous obstacles and empower them to take action on their own behalf to meet their physical, spiritual and emotional needs. This empowerment process allows them to move forward to the future and remove the stigma of their past identities. Our team and partners provide the necessary tools, direction, structure, guidance, and support so that every woman that walks through our door is given the opportunity to succeed. 

Our goal is to help each woman break the cycle of self-destructive behavior; be accountable; take responsibility for her progress; and, learn to solve problems thus avoiding any future contact with the criminal justice system.

Our approach:

Case Management: Provide support and guidance to clients with individualized case plans and targeted goals based on a gender-responsive risk/need/strength assessment.

Substance Abuse Support: Facilitate in-house individual and group interventions and off-campus meetings for recovery and relapse prevention.

Personal Empowerment and Spiritual Support: Facilitate programming in trauma recovery, self-esteem building, stress management, decision-making, healthy relationships, parenting, relationship power, and sexual health. Our programming offers support groups and guidance in empowerment and spiritual growth with daily devotionals and meditation.

Economic Empowerment and Social Enterprises: Conduct entrepreneurship training, mentorship, social enterprise opportunities, and work readiness training. We've created a small social enterprise opportunity to fulfill our mission, generate revenue, and create social and economic opportunities for our program participants.

Health and Wellness: Conduct individualized health assessments plus preventive education addressing negative health behaviors and chronic diseases. Our programming includes instruction on healthy eating, cooking healthy on a budget, and urban gardening skills.


Physical Activity:  Teach individual and organized physical activity such as yoga, running, walking, cycling, high-intensity/short duration workouts, and more.


Hope Rises is a 501(c)3 nonprofit founded in 2013 in Little Rock, Arkansas. 

Our mission is to provide holistic services to incarcerated and previously incarcerated women to improve their health and wellbeing and provide opportunities for personal growth and empowerment.

We currently offer programming to women incarcerated in the Pulaski County Detention Facility. The Hope Rises team is comprised of public health practitioners, a social worker, a health and wellness physician, entrepreneurs, financial manager, and nurses.

 The funds raised from this campaign will be used to finance the opening of our wellness and recovery house. Our goal for the next 60 days is to raise $5,000. This will allow us to pay the initial leasing fees for the facility, make necessary modifications, and purchase the equipment and supplies needed. No donation is too small and there are several ways to give:

  • Make a donation on this site and receive a donation "perk"
  • Visit our website at hoperises.org and set up a recurring monthly donation. Recurring donations are a great way to give. Even a donation as small a $10/month can make an impact.
Your contribution is tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. If goods are provided in the form of perks, the donation in excess of the perk value could be tax-deductible. If we don't reach our $5,000 goal, the "Flexible Funding" option for non-profits will allow us to keep the money and combine the funds with other fundraisers to open our house.

Our Donation Perks:

The Hope Rises donation "perks" are part of an empowerment project we are launching that will help the women connect with their local and global community, learn the elements of design, and learn basic business and marketing skills. This is a social enterprise project where our program participants will work in partnership with women that are part of an empowerment project in South Africa. Our clients will design beadwork that will be handmade by Zulu women. Our clients will then package, market, and sell the products in Little Rock, Arkansas.

Multi-Colored Zulu Bracelet ($50 or more donation)

Long, Multi-Colored Zulu Necklace ($50 or more donation)

Large Globe, Multi-Colored Zulu Necklace ($100 or more donation)

 We know that some of you just can't make a financial contribution at this time, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Tell our story! Please spread the word and share our campaign with your family and friends. Use Indiegogo's share tools to share our campaign on social media.
  • Volunteer! Check our website at hoperises.org or call us at 501-772-7752 and find out how you can donate your time.
  • Donate furnishings and household goods! Check our website for a list of items needed for the house. Call us at 501-772-7752 and we will pick it up!
  • Shop! Our social enterprise products are coming soon.
  • Pray! Pray for our team and for every woman that crosses the threshold of our recovery house.

story:
The Baricaua Group from RE/MAX Our Town invites you to join us at the 5th annual Raising the Stakes for a Miracle Charity Casino Night on Friday, November 13, 2015 from 8pm to 12 am at The Imperia in Somerset, NJ. This charity event will benefit our local Children's Miracle Network Hospitals beneficiary, Children's Specialized Hospital.

Children’s Specialized Hospital is the largest pediatric rehabilitation system in the United States, with thirteen sites in New Jersey. The hospital will treat over 26,000 children with special needs this year ranging from brain injury, spinal cord injury,
premature birth, autism, developmental delays, and other illnesses. These local children will receive first-rate therapy and support services from award-winning staff and programs.

100% of the proceeds will be donated to Children's Specialized Hospital. Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this worthy cause and don't forget to share your #FightFace #FortheKids!

story:
My name is Gabriel Gendreau and I have been developing Wet Wizard Sauce Company over the last year. I am bringing three products to market; pear habanero, harissa, and apple jalapeño barbecue. I've gotten a lot done on personal time with spare cash, but the last few steps before sauce can go from the stove to bottles on a shelf are quite costly. So far I have:

  • Fine tuned three tasty recipes
  • Cooked countless batches of sauce
  • Completed a Better Process Control course and received certification to properly and safely bottle shelf stable food products
  • Taken all three products to a food lab for pH tests, nutritional information, and a proposed process for bottling

I've come a long way but here's what's left:

  • Department of Agriculture licensing
  • Process approval from process authority
  • Insurance
  • Bottles, caps, and labels
  • Shipping packaging
  • pH meter
  • Produce and spices
To show my appreciation I have some great rewards available, including stickers, drink coozies, shirts, and a really cool prize for anybody that ever wanted to name a wizard. Also, a contribution of any amount will get your name listed on a page of contributors on the Wet Wizard website.

Every bit of support will help get a new small business off the ground and fulfill a dream of mine that has been in the works for quite some time.


Supporting Wet Wizard is possible in many ways, please share this campaign and help get the word out. Thank You!

story:
Tod's Dream

My name is Tod O'Leary.  After a career that spanned almost 35 years in the commercial airline industry, I was given the the bad news that my job was being outsourced.  I decided to take the meager savings that I had and invest it into one of my biggest passions...gardening and farming!  I've been an avid gardener my whole life and what better choice for a new career than farming!  My wife of 37 years and I moved to North Carolina in 1988.  We've raised four children here on a 5.5 acre piece of land.  I was showed "Aquaponic Farming" by a friend and decided to pursue that method of farming due to it being "chemical and pesticide free".  Using my savings combined with my retirement fund (approx. $32,000) I built a 3000 sq. ft. greenhouse that is the heart of the aquaponic system.  

This fundraising campaign's purpose is to raise the money to finish the interior part of the greenhouse build.  An additional $20,000 is needed to finish the project.  This project is very important to me not only so I can support my household, but also because it's something I love and believe in. This method of farming brings an awareness of chemical free, sustainable farming to the community and beyond.  I plan to provide tours of the farm for the local schools and colleges to spread the word. 

Only with your help will I be able to realize my dream of sustainable farming.  As we all know, traditional ways of farming are not as efficient as they could be.   I am trying to do my part in progressive farming practices, as I believe it is the best way we can all live with nature on our little planet!


What We Need & What You Get

There is much to be done to get the farm up and running.  The first task after completion of the fundraising campaign would be to order and build the remaining equipment needed to run the operation.  The equipment needed is vast, such as a temperature controlled venting system for green house (GH), retractable shade cloth for the GH, both the main and the backup water pumps for the "deep water system" and "media beds", secondary water pumps for the "vertical towers" and the "nutrient film technology(NFT) systems, air pumps (for oxygenation), 1500 gal. food grade fish tank, a 500 gal. and a 250 gal. filter tank, degassing tank, the materials to build the deep water troughs, media beds, vertical towers, and NFT system (wood, liners, insulation, hardware, epoxy's, etc.) nursery (for starting young seeds/plants), walk-in refrigerated cooler, electrical, plumbing, and aeration materials.  As you can see the list is long and costly and that is why I need your help to get to the finish line.

You can learn more details about the perks of being a contributor over in the perks section, where I'm offering apparel such as shirts, a hat, and merchandise like water bottles, totes, charging cables, and insulated lunch bags.  For higher levels of contribution, I'm even willing to name the greenhouse after you, or put your name on a special plaque that I'll hang in the greenhouse, honoring you as a supporter of sustainable farming!  It will be a highlight of my farm tours!


** Tax deductible contribution receipts will be sent AFTER greenhouse production start up.

** Retractable charging cables are compatible with iPhone 5/6, micro USB devices and Samsung 30-pin devices.  Can charge multiple devices at one time.

** If my entire goal does not get met, I will scale down the operation wherever necessary, while still getting the dream off the ground.

** Tee shirts come in 4 sizes...MED, LG, XLG, and 2XL.

The Impact

We believe this project is very valuable, not only in creating a new business in the community, but also changing the way America and the World farms.  The system is a "closed" system that does not create any type of pollutants (it cleans itself using natures natural life cycles).  This method of farming is being implemented in arid countries around the world, due to the way water is conserved (water is not wasted through percolation or evaporation).  Aquaponic farming typically uses between 5 and 10 percent of the water needed in traditional farming.


Risks & Challenges

Problems and hurdles come with the territory when it comes to running a farming operation, and those issues will be overcome.  The support that is out there for me to take full advantage of gives me strong confidence in my success.  I completed a commercial aquaponic farming training course and have the support and backing from the course's instructors and organization.  There also exists a coalition of Aquaponic Farmers in the North Carolina region that I will join and utilize as another powerful resource.  I have gardened my whole life, growing, canning, and freezing my produce.  This has allowed me to feed my family (and some friends!), some of the highest quality vegetables and fruits.  I am ready for the challenges that await!


Other Ways You Can Help

I know there are some of you that just can't afford to help out with a donation.  You still can be a huge help.  If you believe this is a viable and worthwhile en devour, PLEASE get the word out to others that may!  There are social media sharing links/button here on this Indiegogo campaign page that you can use to spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, Google+, email and more, at the click of a button. Using those tools will help me out a whole lot, too, so thank you for any voice you can lend to the effort.
story_txt:
Tod's Dream My name is Tod O'Leary.  After a career that spanned almost 35 years in the commercial airline industry, I was given the the bad news that my job was being outsourced.  I decided to take the meager savings that I had and invest it into one of my biggest passions...gardening and farming!  I've been an avid gardener my whole life and what better choice for a new career than farming!  My wife of 37 years and I moved to North Carolina in 1988.  We've raised four children here on a 5.5 acre piece of land.  I was showed "Aquaponic Farming" by a friend and decided to pursue that method of farming due to it being "chemical and pesticide free".  Using my savings combined with my retirement fund (approx. $32,000) I built a 3000 sq. ft. greenhouse that is the heart of the aquaponic system.  
This fundraising campaign's purpose is to raise the money to finish the interior part of the greenhouse build.  An additional $20,000 is needed to finish the project.  This project is very important to me not only so I can support my household, but also because it's something I love and believe in. This method of farming brings an awareness of chemical free, sustainable farming to the community and beyond.  I plan to provide tours of the farm for the local schools and colleges to spread the word.  
Only with your help will I be able to realize my dream of sustainable farming.  As we all know, traditional ways of farming are not as efficient as they could be.   I am trying to do my part in progressive farming practices, as I believe it is the best way we can all live with nature on our little planet!
   What We Need & What You Get There is much to be done to get the farm up and running.  The first task after completion of the fundraising campaign would be to order and build the remaining equipment needed to run the operation.  The equipment needed is vast, such as a temperature controlled venting system for green house (GH), retractable shade cloth for the GH, both the main and the backup water pumps for the "deep water system" and "media beds", secondary water pumps for the "vertical towers" and the "nutrient film technology(NFT) systems, air pumps (for oxygenation), 1500 gal. food grade fish tank, a 500 gal. and a 250 gal. filter tank, degassing tank, the materials to build the deep water troughs, media beds, vertical towers, and NFT system (wood, liners, insulation, hardware, epoxy's, etc.) nursery (for starting young seeds/plants), walk-in refrigerated cooler, electrical, plumbing, and aeration materials.  As you can see the list is long and costly and that is why I need your help to get to the finish line.You can learn more details about the perks of being a contributor over in the perks section, where I'm offering apparel such as shirts, a hat, and merchandise like water bottles, totes, charging cables, and insulated lunch bags.  For higher levels of contribution, I'm even willing to name the greenhouse after you, or put your name on a special plaque that I'll hang in the greenhouse, honoring you as a supporter of sustainable farming!  It will be a highlight of my farm tours!
** Tax deductible contribution receipts will be sent AFTER greenhouse production start up.** Retractable charging cables are compatible with iPhone 5/6, micro USB devices and Samsung 30-pin devices.  Can charge multiple devices at one time.** If my entire goal does not get met, I will scale down the operation wherever necessary, while still getting the dream off the ground.** Tee shirts come in 4 sizes...MED, LG, XLG, and 2XL.   The Impact We believe this project is very valuable, not only in creating a new business in the community, but also changing the way America and the World farms.  The system is a "closed" system that does not create any type of pollutants (it cleans itself using natures natural life cycles).  This method of farming is being implemented in arid countries around the world, due to the way water is conserved (water is not wasted through percolation or evaporation).  Aquaponic farming typically uses between 5 and 10 percent of the water needed in traditional farming.

    Risks & Challenges Problems and hurdles come with the territory when it comes to running a farming operation, and those issues will be overcome.  The support that is out there for me to take full advantage of gives me strong confidence in my success.  I completed a commercial aquaponic farming training course and have the support and backing from the course's instructors and organization.  There also exists a coalition of Aquaponic Farmers in the North Carolina region that I will join and utilize as another powerful resource.  I have gardened my whole life, growing, canning, and freezing my produce.  This has allowed me to feed my family (and some friends!), some of the highest quality vegetables and fruits.  I am ready for the challenges that await!
   Other Ways You Can Help I know there are some of you that just can't afford to help out with a donation.  You still can be a huge help.  If you believe this is a viable and worthwhile en devour, PLEASE get the word out to others that may!  There are social media sharing links/button here on this Indiegogo campaign page that you can use to spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, Google+, email and more, at the click of a button. Using those tools will help me out a whole lot, too, so thank you for any voice you can lend to the effort.

story:
What is LionHeart Sports? 

LionHeart Sports is a small sports company with big ambitions. Currently we are a mobile company but hope to change that in the future. We are based out of Monroe, Ohio and will be serving the greater Cincinnati and Dayton area. Right now we are going to offer the sports of Knockerball and Archery Tag with hopes to expand to other sports later on.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking each of you to help us reach our goal of $15,000 for our startup. $12,000 of the startup costs will be for the equipment and licensing for the sports. The other $3,000 will be used for any other expenses we will need such as, logo and website design, marketing our new company and brand, equipment for payments and traveling expenses to help get the word out.

In return for donating you will receive a perk (coupon) towards our services once we get started. For example, if you donate $100 you will receive a $200 credit towards our services (Archery Tag and/or Knocker Ball) and a free T-shirt.

If we do not reach our goal of $15,000 we plan to use what we raise and put 100% towards the equipment and licensing costs. 

The Impact/Our Goal

Once we officially launch we want to have a huge impact on our community. This could include anything from raising money for charities to providing an after prom party for schools. Most importantly, we want to have a positive impact on our community in any way possible.

Risks/Challenges

Our biggest challenge right now is getting the money for the equipment and licensing along with getting our word out and promoting our brand.

Other Ways You Can Help

- Tell everyone about us 

- Share on any and all Social Media

story:
Help Us Support Dog Rescue Groups Today


The Passion and Intention

Mary Paulson and Surinder Goode's personal missions are to begin a new journey within  San Diego community's craft breweries, wineries and ciders, to become one of the leading cider-makers, and utilizing their status as an advocate and volunteer for dog rescues, primarily with Labradors and Friends Dog Rescue Group by donating a 10% portion of profits from hard ciders to animal rescue charities.

  

Mary's business and life philosophy stems from a core belief in possibilities, and in believing that whatever you set your heart and mind out to do in life, you will accomplish your goals. She has proven this to be true by following her passions. First, as a touring and recording artist with two albums, then as a fire fighter retiring after 26 years of service, and as a LPGA Class A Golf Professional,  she has accomplished all of her past career goals.

Knowing that when one journey ends, another begins with new goals, new dreams, and new possibilities waiting to be challenged and fulfilled. In 2015, Mary found her life transitioning towards focusing on cider-making and volunteer work. Now her passion is to create great tasting hard cider, volunteer to foster rescue Labrador mixed dogs, and to become an active participant in her community in the North Park district of San Diego, CA.

            
Senior Bonded-Pair Spot and Poochie:  Picture taken just after being dropped off by their family at a High Kill Shelter in Los Angeles ages 8 and 10.
by Fusaro Photography

               

At the age of 50, all of Mary's past hard work took a toll,  her past injuries caught up to her, and health issues became a priority. It was time to take a time out and care for herself for a bit. Mary found herself in physical therapy for 11 months working on all her injuries and starting a new hobby making hard cider. She shared and tested each new recipe and flavor with her PT doctor and massage therapist until each flavor was perfect!   Now her focus has become fostering Labradors, rehabilitating from her injuries, and making hard ciders subsequently naming it, Poochie's Hooch!

                         

Poochie's Hooch is named after a foster Labrador mix dog named Poochie. She came to the rescue group as half of a senior bonded pair. Today, sadly, her mate, Spot, has passed on and Poochie is now 11 years old, alone, and most likely will never be adopted. She will be considered a "Foster Failure".  Mary and her business partner, Surinder, plan to give 10% net profits to Labradors & Friends Dog Rescue each year as a business charity, specifically to aid special funding for medical aid, medications, food and bedding for senior dogs.                                                                                                                            

             


This will be a contribution that will continue to give help to those in need.

These two hard working women guarantee that the money funded to aid in start- up costs for Poochie's Hooch Urban Cidery will be used tenfold for years to come in paying forward and giving to charities for animal rights, and specifically caring for senior dogs who are dumped in shelters by their "families" because they are too old or sick; moving away without them, or just don't want to be responsible for their pet any more. Rescue groups, like Labradors and Friends, pull these dogs out of High Kill Shelters and give them help, dignity, and hopefully, new loving families and homes every day. In 2015, LAFDR rescued 401 dogs in need.  But in the cases like Poochie, which are many, they are held in boarding facilities, or hopefully a loving foster home until they are adopted, or sadly cross over the rainbow bridge in loving arms.

                             


Surinder Goode has spent her entire career in the food and beverage industry.

In 1988 Surinder joined Harlequin Leisure Group as a manager of a chain of Indian restaurants in Scotland. From menu planning, décor, to hiring and training employees Surinder’s job encompassed all aspects of the restaurant industry.  In 1991, Surinder moved to the Middle East operating on board private flights for His Royal Highness. Traveling the world and expanding her knowledge of food and wines, she became involved in catering to an elite clientele.

After moving to San Diego, despite reaching corporate goals, in 2002, Surinder challenged herself by opening her first coffee kiosk to a demographic of disciplined, hardworking, patriotic individuals ... the U.S. Military ... a demographic that had not been catered to.

“After several months of operating, one of my dearest customers paid me a tremendous business compliment by saying, “Your coffee cart is known as the ‘water cooler’ on base”.  The “Water Cooler” became the model for business.


LOSE THE POOCH, DRINK SOME HOOCH

   

Mary created a healthy formula for her hard cider only containing 8 grams of carbohydrates and 8 grams of sugar with 280 cal in 16oz servings at 7.35% abv. To say she was pleased with these laboratory results would be an understatement, since most commercial hard ciders on the market today contain 19-26 grams of sugar in 12 oz. servings!  Poochie's Hooch is easy on the tummy and oh so yummy, because sugar-minded people are able to drink several servings without feeling any after-affects the next morning!

Using only natural and organic ingredients, it quickly became clear that this cider was special! The light, crisp, low sugar beverage was becoming a favorite at social events, parties, and get-togethers with friends and neighbors. The perfect alcoholic beverage at a Renaissance themed wedding.... Spiced Apple and Jaded Apple!
    

With 20 different flavored hard ciders, the feedback Mary continued to receive about her hooch from friends, neighbors, strangers, professional wine tasters and brew masters all told her to take her product to the commercial level with no reservations.  Open a cider house. Thus creating The Cider House, LLC    DBA Poochie's Hooch Urban Cidery.

"The Apple Mojito is amazing! Perfect to sip on a hot summer day or evening."

Quoting Rusty Figgins, "Keep the Pumpkin Spice on tap year round. They will come back for this cider."

That was enough for Mary to follow yet another journey towards yet another soon to be successful goal... Poochie's Hooch Urban Cidery.

The cidery will be located within the North Park District in San Diego, known as the Craft Brewery Mecca in the United States. Poochie's Hooch Urban Cidery will be the first cider house, not only among the high density craft breweries in North Park, but also in the entire city of San Diego. Those looking for something different other than beer while touring North Park establishments will now have Poochie's Hooch hard cider to enjoy!  This business is set up for success! Great product, Great location, Great successful business owners, and great passion for charity and community!

To quote Mary's past golf coaches and anyone who has worked with her on any project, "Action" is the one word to describe Mary Paulson. She does what she says she's going to do. She walks the walk, and talks the talk. With all of her high goals and aspirations, she has never given up and always saw each project to the end of every journey successfully meeting her goals. Poochie's Hooch will be yet another successful journey for decades to come.


What We Need & What We Are Asking
Mary and her business partner, Surinder, who has over 15 years owning and operating her current beverage business, are currently asking aid for $75,000 to help attain a location lease and order the fermenting equipment, in order to begin the Application process for Licenses and Permits, and ultimately,  to open a hard cider manufacturing business.  With the initial intent to start selling through a tasting room and manufacturing 520 barrels annually, then using annual profits to expand and open two more Tap rooms across southern California.  Opening an alcoholic manufacturing business comes with more red tape and paperwork at the Federal, State, and Local governmental levels than most new small businesses. Costs for legal fees and hiring Attorneys who specialize in the Wine/Cider/Craft brewery will cost $10-20k. Taxes, Insurance, Licensing and permits, and professional fees will cost $50k.  $100k will be spent on purchasing manufacturing equipment and supplies for a 20 Barrel fermenting system, building a customized cooling system, shipping and installing the system with professional  training by the manufacturing company; and  preparing the Cidery building itself for the fermenting tanks to meet regulations IE: Floor drains, cement weight-load platforms, electrical, plumbing, and Installing walk-in coolers and a freezer, will estimate a cost $30k. Our total Start up/Capital needs will be $200,000. But your help will keep the movement towards opening scheduled by March 2017, if not sooner.

In summary, The funding we are asking for will be utilized to get the actual Cidery up and running and producing, along with furnishing the tasting room and setting up a tap system for 10 flavors of cider available at one time year round. Because of the red tape in receiving licenses and permits from Fed/State/local governments, the most expensive cost will be Property lease and utilities. It will take at least 6 months from the time of the Federal TTB application process has started, 3 months for the fermenting equipment to be manufactured, 2-3 months for State ABC winegrowers permits to be approved, and a month and a day to make a batch of hooch until we can open for business. Yet another reason why many home cider-makers do not commercialize. You must have an address and location in the TTB application for wine manufacturing, as well as, show paperwork that the fermenting equipment is on order. This alone will cost approximately $100k for paying 6 months lease with a deposit and ordering equipment..

So what do we get out of it? $200k to show the Realtor, equipment manufacturer, and government entities we have enough funds in the bank to lease the property location we know we want within the craft brewery district of North Park, and to show TTB we are prepared to move forward to manufacture hard ciders. This will allow us to move forward with the rest of the business preparations by hiring contractors and professionals for building construction, permits, legal aid, etc. And to begin creating jobs in our community by hiring workers for the tasting room and Assistant cider makers.
 

                       

What do you get out of it? Aside from the perks we will offer for smaller contributions, we are also in a position to negotiate with donors offering $50k+. This will be discussed privately, and those seriously interested in higher propositions may contact us for the Secret Perks and will be sent to you.

We are truly looking for a win-win-win situation.

We want the rescued and non-rescued dogs to win, we obviously want our new Urban Cidery to win, and for believing in our cause, our passion, Mary's great natural pallet and cider making skills, and our sense of adventure we want you, the donors, to win too!  Whether it be a logo cap or branded flight board with glasses; a CD of Mary Paulson or a Private Professional Golf lesson;

       


 A Private Personal Training session with  Surinder.  A Private Tasting Party with your friends, or having your name recognized on the "Poochie" wall as a contributor for Dog Rescues; a good karma sticker, or just a heart-felt and grateful Thank You, knowing your contribution will be a gift that will continue to give and grow.  We want you to feel as much passion as we do to serve our community and help animal rights. 
            

Reaching our goal would be tremendous. But even if we only receive half of our needs, that still allows us to get the ball rolling. We can get into our building, get our applications sent in, get our manufacturing equipment ordered, and that will give us 6 months to find more funds to hire attorneys for unforeseen issues, And get the tasting room constructed and ready for a grand opening.

  

                   CHEERS!  


 Note from Mary:

As a retired firefighter, I have been looking to reinvent myself; to feel needed and a part of the community again. I want to help. I know I can do a lot of good for others who help needy animals every day. I got lucky and began making an incredible hard cider! The cidery alone will be a success because there are NO cider houses among the craft breweries in the North Park brewery district. There will be zero competition. A No-Brainer for this location and market.  Your money will help us to make hard cider, so that we can pay it forward and help the non-profit charities who help those tossed and dumped beautiful animals, and hopefully connect them with new loving families.  Thank you for allowing me to share Poochie's story, and explain why I'm so passionate about opening our urban cidery in San Diego.
Mary~

story: NA

Hi! I’m Belen, I'm Argentinian, but I live in Arequipa (Peru) since 6 years ago. I am married and we have three children, Máximo, Francisco and Clara, and I’m proofreader.

I have a dream

Open a Bookstore coffee shop and cultural meeting place. But before going into details, I tell you that Arequipa is surrounded by 3 volcanoes; it has a spring weather for 9 consecutive months in the year; it is a city with an estimated population of 1 million; big, right? But it still has a detail, in this city so populated there is not even a single bookstore-coffee. This means that there is no one place where you can choose a book and drink a coffee, where you can relax and have a good time, and where can also fill you with other things that enrich your soul.

Why?

I want people to not only have the possibility of buying a book, but also that this place were a cultural site that contribute to the society, Peruvians and the large number of foreigners who visit the city throughout the year. Here there will be story-telling, book presentations, live relaxing music, comic books workshops, reading clubs. It will be a place for practicing book crossing. At the same time, those people who do not have enough money, can take second hand books at very low cost or join book crossing. In this bookstore, readers will be able to recommend books to others in a specific site for it.

It will be a great place where we will all be enriched!

You can take part!

Now, to achieve this I need your help. These are the expenses that I must to cover in order to avoid getting into debt so much at the beginning:

  • $18,200 to cover the rent of the premises for a time.
  • $5,000 to condition the premises and make it as beautiful as posible.
  • $6,000 for furniture and decoration.
  • $30,000 for books.
  • $40,800 to cover extra expenses: shelves and booksellers; tableware and initial supplies; municipal licenses; signs; professional services; Indiegogo (8% of funds raised —including platform and credit card charges— + 30 cents per contribution); cost of perks + shipping (included in the perk cost).

Thus I need $100,000. I know it's a lot of money but I'm sure you'll love the project, and when you visit this beautiful city, you will can see it came true!

Perks

Now, if you help me, you will receive in return:

  • For contributions of $10: Special thanks by email + an eternal gratitude.
  • For contributions of $25: A postcard of Arequipa city + an eternal gratitude.
  • For contributions of $50: A watercolor painting of some landscape of the city made by a Peruvian artist (5,90’’ x 2,36’’ approx.) + an eternal gratitude.
  • For the contributions of $75: The two previous perks + an eternal gratitude.
  • For contributions of $100: A watercolor painting of some city landscape made by a Peruvian artist (5,11’’ x 7,08’’ approx.) + an eternal gratitude.
  • For the contributions of $250: A book of the Nobel Prize Mario Vargas Llosa + an eternal gratitude.
  • For the contributions of $300: A book of the cartoonists Quino or Liniers (to put an Argentinian touch) + a watercolor painting (5,90’’ x 2,36’’ approx.) + an eternal gratitude.
  • For contributions of $500: A Peruvian recipe book of the renowned chef Gastón Acurio + an eternal gratitude.

And if you cannot help me economically, I thank you very much for the diffusion of my campaign, this will allow me to reach more people.

For this and your desire to have arrived here, I thank you with all my heart!

Cheers!

Belen

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

¡Hola a todos! Mi nombre es Belén. Soy argentina, pero vivo desde hace 6 años en Arequipa, una ciudad al sur del Perú. Estoy casada y tenemos tres hijos, Máximo, Francisco y Clara; y trabajo como correctora de textos.

Mi sueño

Poner una librería-café que también sirva de espacio cultural. Pero antes de entrar en detalles, te cuento que Arequipa está rodeada de 3 volcanes, tiene clima primaveral por 9 meses seguidos en el año y es una ciudad de más de un millón de habitantes. Grande, ¿no? Pero aun así tiene un detalle, y es que en esta ciudad tan poblada no hay ni una sola librería-café. Esto significa que no existe un espacio en donde puedas escoger un libro y tomar un rico café, en donde puedas relajarte y quedarte a pasar un buen rato, y en donde además te llenes de otras cosas que enriquecen tu alma.

¿Por qué?

Quiero que la gente no solo tenga la posibilidad de comprar un libro, sino también que este espacio sea un sitio cultural que aporte a la sociedad, para los peruanos y para la gran cantidad de extranjeros que visitan la ciudad durante todo el año. Habrá cuenta-cuentos para los niños, presentaciones de libros, música relajante en vivo, talleres de cómics, clubs de lecturas, charlas. También habrá un espacio de intercambio de libros, es decir, dejar uno ya leído y llevarse otro, lo cual genera una invitación extra para leer. A su vez, aquellas personas que no tengan suficiente dinero, podrán llevarse obras de segunda mano a muy bajo costo, o sumarse al intercambio. En mi local habrá un espacio destinado para que los clientes puedan recomendar libros a otros lectores.

¡Será un gran lugar en donde nos enriqueceremos todos!

¡Tú puedes ser parte!

Para lograrlo necesito de tu ayuda. Estos son los gastos que debo cubrir para evitar endeudarme tanto al inicio:

  • $ 18,200 para cubrir el alquiler del local por un tiempo.
  • $ 5,000 para acondicionar el negocio y dejarlo lo más bonito posible.
  • $ 6,000 para muebles y decoración.
  • $ 30,000 para los libros.
  • $ 40,800 para cubrir gastos extras: estanterías y libreros; vajillas e insumos iniciales; licencias municipales; letreros; servicios profesionales; Indiegogo (8 % de los fondos recaudados —incluye cargos por plataforma y tarjeta de crédito— + 30 centavos por contribución); costo de las recompensas + el envío (está incluido en el valor de las mismas).

Es decir que necesito $ 100,000, sé que es mucha plata, pero estoy segura de que te encantará el proyecto, y cuando andes por esta bella ciudad, ¡podrás verlo hecho realidad!

Recompensas

Ahora, quiero contarte qué te llevarás a cambio si me ayudas a conseguirlo:

  • Para los aportes de $ 10: Un agradecimiento especial por correo electrónico + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 25: Una postal de la ciudad de Arequipa + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 50: Una pintura en acuarela de algún paisaje de la ciudad hecha por un artista peruano (15 x 6 cm aprox.) + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 75: Las dos recompensas anteriores + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 100: Una pintura en acuarela de algún paisaje de la ciudad hecha por un artista peruano (13 x 18 cm aprox.) + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 250: Un libro del Premio Nobel Mario Vargas Llosa + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 300: Un libro de los historietistas Quino o Liniers (para poner un toque argentino) + una pintura en acuarela (15 x 6 cm aprox.) + una eterna gratitud.
  • Para los aportes de $ 500: Un libro de recetas peruanas del reconocido chef Gastón Acurio + una eterna gratitud.

Y si no puedes ayudarme económicamente, te agradezco muchísimo la difusión de mi campaña, esto me permitirá llegar a más personas.

Por esto y por tus ganas de haber llegado hasta aquí, ¡te agradezco de todo corazón!

Con cariño.

Belén

Single dollars lead to hundreds, and hundreds lead to thousands...PLEASE DONATE TODAY.  THANK YOU SO MUCH!

story:
Nothing Can Dim the Light that Shines from Within

HELP TWO BEST FRIENDS WITH ONE DREAM TO OPEN THEIR HEALTH AND WELLNESS SPA!

When best friends Kathy McKinstry and Sara Burrows-Jacques decided to form a partnership and open their very own luxury health and wellness spa over two years ago, the two loving wives and mothers had no idea the trials and tribulations they would endure while establishing themselves as entrepreneurs.

The unlikely pair met about six years ago when Sara was seeking for a daycare provider for her two young daughters and found Kathy, a retired Marine, housewife, and mother to two beautiful daughters of her own.  It wasn’t long before the arrangement bloomed into a forever friendship. Instantly, the two families became inseparable until this past May when Kathy’s husband Marcus unexpectantly passed away due to the onset of a brain aneurysm.

Soon after his passing, Kathy and the girls moved to Ohio to live closer to Marcus’s family. It seemed their plans would be postponed while Kathy took time to adjust to her new normal and grieve. But true to her nature, the retired marine mom stepped up and started making plans for her and her daughters’ futures. She and Sara were going to open that spa, and nothing was going to stop them.

Sara was so excited! She had been in the health and wellness industry for over 17 years and now she was finally getting her own place of business to serve others. Sara’s love and passion have always been in helping others feel good! She knows when people feel good, they treat others better, so servicing clients is her way of making our world a better place.

And for Kathy, she had always dreamed of having her own business and being her own boss! So, they searched high and low around Murrieta, California for the perfect location and began making plans to open their new luxury health and wellness spa, Noor Day Spa this Spring.

However, due to delays in renovation and obtaining specific permits, these two best friends and newbie entrepreneurs have run into a few snags that are costing them more money than they had planned for.

Funds are still needed to help pay for equipment, interior design, supplies, advertising, and more and the opening date is right around the corner.

 

 

The good thing is

YOU CAN HELP!

You can be a bright light in a time of darkness and support The Bright Light Campaign! You can help spread light by helping Sara and Kathy open their doors to the community of Murrieta, CA this Spring.

Incentives and rewards will be given to everyone who contributes to The Bright Light Campaign. Help Spread Light!

This campaign is dedicated to the memory of loving husband, father and Marine Veteran, Marcus McKinstry.

Follow and support our journey online

                    Facebook:   N00r Day Spa    Instagram:      @N00r_Day_Spa

story:
The Story.

Neil Gaiman says in his book American Gods: “…a town isn’t a town without a bookstore. It may call itself a town, but unless it’s got a bookstore, it knows it’s not foolin’ a soul.” This is absolutely true – bookstores offer joy and knowledge, nurture imaginations and creativity, and bring people and ideas together. They build community.

And there was a good chance that Vallejo was going to lose its only one.

But when the owner of the Vallejo Bookstore contacted me and told me she wanted to sell and asked if I would be interested in buying it, my first reaction was, “Yes!” Ever since I was a teenager it has been my dream to own my own bookstore, especially after working in the book business for nearly 30 years, first as a bookseller, and for the past 15 years in sales for Lonely Planet and Chronicle Books. But because of that experience, I did think long and hard about it. I’ve watched the book industry change, from independents to chain stores to superstores to internet to the “death of the book” to “books are making a comeback” to everything in between. But one thing has stayed consistent: me. I love books, I love reading, I love talking about books, I love recommending books, I love selling books, I love independent bookstores. Even after all that thinking and weighing it all out, I still said, “Yes!” This is what I’ve always wanted to do, and what I believe in.

I also believe in Vallejo, California, which is about 30 miles north of San Francisco and the 10th most populated city in The Bay Area. It declared bankruptcy in 2008, but has been on the upswing and continues to see positive changes. Buying the bookstore is an opportunity to keep a business downtown. And like Neil Gaiman said, a town isn’t a town without a bookstore, and I don’t want Vallejo to lose ours; I want Vallejo to continue to have a bookstore to serve our community as a thriving business with events, readings, story times for kids, and, of course, books! Mostly I want it to be a place for people to meet, to share, and be welcoming for all. I think Alibi Bookshop will be a terrific asset for Vallejo, especially downtown, and I think I am the right person to do this and make a positive impact for our city.

 

What We Need 

My goal to get going is $30,000, which sounds like a lot (and it is!) but it is actually quite conservative. There are many things to consider and it will be used for the following: start-up costs (business license, DBA, resale certificate paperwork processing; LLC and ABA membership fees; insurance; utilities; deposits) POS upgrade, signage, fixtures (bookshelves; tables; display items; furniture; office desk), marketing (materials and online), floor and window repair, supplies, and most of all, inventory and merchandise. Though it will continue to be primarily used books, I do want to bring in popular new titles, requested favorites, gifts and sidelines, and need to establish credit with distributors and publishers.

Since I’ve been in the book business for all these years, I’m not exactly wealthy so I need financial assistance. Believe me, it’s not easy for me to do this, but I am such a strong believer in independent bookstores, my town, and fellow readers, that I’m swallowing my pride and asking for your help. It’s going to be a lot of work and will take a village, but I know the end result is going to be rewarding for all of us. And the perks will be especially rewarding for you -- check them out! Click on the sidebar to the right to see what each of them include.

 

Risks, Challenges, and Impact

I know in this day and age of Amazon and big box stores, buying a small business – especially a brick and mortar bookstore – is risky. But print book sales are up and independent bookstores have been thriving for the past few years – there are now over 2300 in the US. (Take a look at all these articles: https://www.bookweb.org/for-the-record …and look what’s anchoring downtowns! https://commonwealthmagazine.org/economy/guess-whats-anchoring-many-small-downtowns/) And as someone who has been working in publishing for the past 16 years, I have seen firsthand the power, enthusiasm, and success of these independent bookstores and their dedicated owners and staff, and I’m thrilled to be joining their ranks. Also, the Shop Local movement is gaining more and more momentum -- people are starting to understand that the money that is spent in local stores gives back to the community. Shopping online isn’t going to help your town as much as shopping in your local businesses does. And we give people what online retailers can’t: real human connection, thoughtful recommendations instead of algorithms, and experience. They may discount deeply, but what we offer is priceless.

Downtown Vallejo is another risk, but I think it won’t be for long. As of now, there are empty storefronts, and not a lot of regular foot traffic. However, there is The Vallejo Artwalk on the 2nd Friday evening of the month, and every Saturday there is a popular and fantastic farmer’s market, and more businesses are starting to move in. The beautiful Empress Theater is around the corner, as is Provisions, one of the most delicious restaurants in The Bay Area. Across the street is Spruce, what started as a pop-up shop on the holidays, and has been so successful that they signed a lease! I also want to open on Sundays so that the store is a destination for events and shopping. I feel that by keeping the bookstore in business will help inspire more businesses to continue moving in, too, and it will continue to help our economy. Vallejo residents have a fierce pride in their city, and want downtown to thrive. By keeping the bookstore open, we can do just that.

So it may be risky to buy a small bookstore, but I know what I will be giving back to Vallejo and the Bay Area will mitigate those risks and be a success. We’re definitely in for a lot of hard work. (No sitting around reading with a cat on my lap!) I will be keeping my job and working at the store on weekends, and finding staff for the rest of the week. My husband (who is in 1000%!) will be helping out, too, and doing the accounting. There’s a lot of set-up and buying and planning and marketing and brainstorming and hosting and selling to do, and I CANNOT WAIT. The amount of support I’ve received since announcing my plan has been overwhelmingly positive, and I know I’m doing the right thing to make this happen – right by Vallejo and its people, and right in making my bookstore dream come true. As my friend of 30 years said when I told her, “You were born to do this.” I was!

 

About Us... And the Store

I’ve lived in The Bay Area for nearly my whole life, and moved to Vallejo a few years ago. My first job was in a bookstore; my last job will be, too. Since that first job I’ve also worked in Publishing (and at a vintage clothing store, where I learned a lot about small business), and have an MFA in Creative Writing. I have more books than I will ever read, and like it that way. I’ve been married to my husband, Jon, for 6 years (together for 15) – he’s an accountant who loves records as much as I love books. I have two lovely stepchildren of whom I am so proud, and two tiny dogs named Dorothy Parker and Dino Martina who have more Instagram followers than I do.

The Vallejo Bookstore was originally started in 2014 by Dave Tilton and Dariece Warren who purchased it from Rar Farmer, and then sold it to Shannon Moore-Hartlep in 2017. Shannon has done an amazing job – she moved it to the space it’s in now, and has built a regular base of customers who will miss her so much. But Shannon is moving on to pursue her dreams, and giving me the chance to fulfill mine.

Shannon and I agreed that changing the name was a good idea and symbolic for a new start. I struggled coming up with something – what could be better than “Vallejo Bookstore”? – but a friend pointed me to this article: https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/the-alibi-c... and I knew that was it. The Alibi Clock, which I love, is just around the corner from the store on Georgia Street. It has a fascinating history, and is a nod to Vallejo. It’s perfect!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate financially, I understand! But if you have any books that no longer spark joy for you (but will for someone else) and are in resalable condition – no broken spines, discarded library books, writing, rips, or tears – I will happily take them. Eventually I hope to start a Buy/Sell/Trade program, but have to get going first.

Other ways to help – please share this far and wide! Tell your friends! Follow Alibi Bookshop on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/alibibookshop and Instagram https://www.instagram.com/alibibookshop/ and most of all, come in and shop – often! And if you need a book, contact us and we can order it for you.

Thank you so much for all your support. I truly appreciate it. Looking forward to seeing you at Alibi Bookshop!

It may call itself a town, but unless it’s got a bookstore, it knows it’s not foolin’ a soul.” This is absolutely true – bookstores offer joy and knowledge, nurture imaginations and creativity, and bring people and ideas together. They build community.
And there was a good chance that Vallejo was going to lose its only one.
But when the owner of the Vallejo Bookstore contacted me and told me she wanted to sell and asked if I would be interested in buying it, my first reaction was, “Yes!” Ever since I was a teenager it has been my dream to own my own bookstore, especially after working in the book business for nearly 30 years, first as a bookseller, and for the past 15 years in sales for Lonely Planet and Chronicle Books. But because of that experience, I did think long and hard about it. I’ve watched the book industry change, from independents to chain stores to superstores to internet to the “death of the book” to “books are making a comeback” to everything in between. But one thing has stayed consistent: me. I love books, I love reading, I love talking about books, I love recommending books, I love selling books, I love independent bookstores. Even after all that thinking and weighing it all out, I still said, “Yes!” This is what I’ve always wanted to do, and what I believe in.
I also believe in Vallejo, California, which is about 30 miles north of San Francisco and the 10th most populated city in The Bay Area. It declared bankruptcy in 2008, but has been on the upswing and continues to see positive changes. Buying the bookstore is an opportunity to keep a business downtown. And like Neil Gaiman said, a town isn’t a town without a bookstore, and I don’t want Vallejo to lose ours; I want Vallejo to continue to have a bookstore to serve our community as a thriving business with events, readings, story times for kids, and, of course, books! Mostly I want it to be a place for people to meet, to share, and be welcoming for all. I think Alibi Bookshop will be a terrific asset for Vallejo, especially downtown, and I think I am the right person to do this and make a positive impact for our city.
 

What We Need 
My goal to get going is $30,000, which sounds like a lot (and it is!) but it is actually quite conservative. There are many things to consider and it will be used for the following: start-up costs (business license, DBA, resale certificate paperwork processing; LLC and ABA membership fees; insurance; utilities; deposits) POS upgrade, signage, fixtures (bookshelves; tables; display items; furniture; office desk), marketing (materials and online), floor and window repair, supplies, and most of all, inventory and merchandise. Though it will continue to be primarily used books, I do want to bring in popular new titles, requested favorites, gifts and sidelines, and need to establish credit with distributors and publishers.
Since I’ve been in the book business for all these years, I’m not exactly wealthy so I need financial assistance. Believe me, it’s not easy for me to do this, but I am such a strong believer in independent bookstores, my town, and fellow readers, that I’m swallowing my pride and asking for your help. It’s going to be a lot of work and will take a village, but I know the end result is going to be rewarding for all of us. And the perks will be especially rewarding for you -- check them out! Click on the sidebar to the right to see what each of them include.
 

Risks, Challenges, and Impact
I know in this day and age of Amazon and big box stores, buying a small business – especially a brick and mortar bookstore – is risky. But print book sales are up and independent bookstores have been thriving for the past few years – there are now over 2300 in the US. (Take a look at all these articles: https://www.bookweb.org/for-the-record …and look what’s anchoring downtowns! https://commonwealthmagazine.org/economy/guess-whats-anchoring-many-small-downtowns/) And as someone who has been working in publishing for the past 16 years, I have seen firsthand the power, enthusiasm, and success of these independent bookstores and their dedicated owners and staff, and I’m thrilled to be joining their ranks. Also, the Shop Local movement is gaining more and more momentum -- people are starting to understand that the money that is spent in local stores gives back to the community. Shopping online isn’t going to help your town as much as shopping in your local businesses does. And we give people what online retailers can’t: real human connection, thoughtful recommendations instead of algorithms, and experience. They may discount deeply, but what we offer is priceless.
Downtown Vallejo is another risk, but I think it won’t be for long. As of now, there are empty storefronts, and not a lot of regular foot traffic. However, there is The Vallejo Artwalk on the 2nd Friday evening of the month, and every Saturday there is a popular and fantastic farmer’s market, and more businesses are starting to move in. The beautiful Empress Theater is around the corner, as is Provisions, one of the most delicious restaurants in The Bay Area. Across the street is Spruce, what started as a pop-up shop on the holidays, and has been so successful that they signed a lease! I also want to open on Sundays so that the store is a destination for events and shopping. I feel that by keeping the bookstore in business will help inspire more businesses to continue moving in, too, and it will continue to help our economy. Vallejo residents have a fierce pride in their city, and want downtown to thrive. By keeping the bookstore open, we can do just that.
So it may be risky to buy a small bookstore, but I know what I will be giving back to Vallejo and the Bay Area will mitigate those risks and be a success. We’re definitely in for a lot of hard work. (No sitting around reading with a cat on my lap!) I will be keeping my job and working at the store on weekends, and finding staff for the rest of the week. My husband (who is in 1000%!) will be helping out, too, and doing the accounting. There’s a lot of set-up and buying and planning and marketing and brainstorming and hosting and selling to do, and I CANNOT WAIT. The amount of support I’ve received since announcing my plan has been overwhelmingly positive, and I know I’m doing the right thing to make this happen – right by Vallejo and its people, and right in making my bookstore dream come true. As my friend of 30 years said when I told her, “You were born to do this.” I was!
 

About Us... And the Store
I’ve lived in The Bay Area for nearly my whole life, and moved to Vallejo a few years ago. My first job was in a bookstore; my last job will be, too. Since that first job I’ve also worked in Publishing (and at a vintage clothing store, where I learned a lot about small business), and have an MFA in Creative Writing. I have more books than I will ever read, and like it that way. I’ve been married to my husband, Jon, for 6 years (together for 15) – he’s an accountant who loves records as much as I love books. I have two lovely stepchildren of whom I am so proud, and two tiny dogs named Dorothy Parker and Dino Martina who have more Instagram followers than I do.
The Vallejo Bookstore was originally started in 2014 by Dave Tilton and Dariece Warren who purchased it from Rar Farmer, and then sold it to Shannon Moore-Hartlep in 2017. Shannon has done an amazing job – she moved it to the space it’s in now, and has built a regular base of customers who will miss her so much. But Shannon is moving on to pursue her dreams, and giving me the chance to fulfill mine.
Shannon and I agreed that changing the name was a good idea and symbolic for a new start. I struggled coming up with something – what could be better than “Vallejo Bookstore”? – but a friend pointed me to this article: https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/the-alibi-c... and I knew that was it. The Alibi Clock, which I love, is just around the corner from the store on Georgia Street. It has a fascinating history, and is a nod to Vallejo. It’s perfect!
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t donate financially, I understand! But if you have any books that no longer spark joy for you (but will for someone else) and are in resalable condition – no broken spines, discarded library books, writing, rips, or tears – I will happily take them. Eventually I hope to start a Buy/Sell/Trade program, but have to get going first.
Other ways to help – please share this far and wide! Tell your friends! Follow Alibi Bookshop on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/alibibookshop and Instagram https://www.instagram.com/alibibookshop/ and most of all, come in and shop – often! And if you need a book, contact us and we can order it for you.
Thank you so much for all your support. I truly appreciate it. Looking forward to seeing you at Alibi Bookshop!

story:
Welcome to What Entertainment was Meant to Be!

When my wife and I moved to Northern Arizona in 2013, we were struck by the sheer lack of entertainment options. With 80,000 residents and nearly 3 million tourists annually, the Verde Valley is in great need of family friendly options for evening entertainment. Given our community, one of the things I considered soon went from thought to dream: a classic drive-in theater experience!

The Verde Drive-In's vision is to recapture what entertainment was meant to be. The Verde Drive-In will develop to a multi-screen drive-in theater that capitalizes on our beautiful landscape. The temperate climate allows for more than 9 months of outdoor operation. During our first few years of operation, we will show classic and family films. We will build up capital reserves in order purchase the equipment that can show New Releases. 

To prepare the local market, the Verde Drive-In will operate as a pop-up and mobile theater as a minimum viable product. We will partner with local establishments to secure space and will offer food trucks with high quality and traditional fare. The pop-up will allow the Verde Drive-In to gain local support while keeping expenses low allowing us to grow and stabilize while continuing to secure funding for the next phase. 

What Sets Us Apart

Verde Drive-In has a distinct competitive edge in that it is the only movie theater within 20 miles of our target location and the only Drive-In throughout Northern Arizona. Other community organizations with outdoor movies do not pose a threat because they have a limited run, target a specific audience, and moviegoers do not sit in their vehicles which exposes them to the weather and insects. 

Competition for movie theaters comes in a number of different forms. In general you could describe the indirect competition as any entertainment alternative in the local area, however all local entertainment other than movie theaters will be seen as an ally in creating a family friendly entertainment destination here in the Verde Valley.

Verde Drive-In will differentiate itself from its competitors by creating a family friendly entertainment experience. Research of Drive-Ins across the country have shown that implementing theme nights or limited-run series, as well as photo booths, food trucks, and additional entertainment options have proven successful in creating a quality entertainment experience.

Our advantage is also the beneficial climate which results in an extended season. The weather in the Verde Valley allows for at least 9 months of operation. This will ensure that the Drive-In experience remains attractive and enjoyable to customers.

Drive-In theaters are opening across the country as 'Retro' is coming back. We will capitalize on the nostalgia the Baby Boomer generation has towards Drive-In theaters. To aid in the Classic / Retro experience, we will show classics and 2nd run films at the Verde Pop-Up.

What We Need & What You Get

The Verde Pop-Up will attract traditional movie-going customers and those that enjoy classics from the 1940’s to 1990’s. We will operate in a portable pop-up model greatly reducing start-up costs. This will create a more sustainable model because our mobile equipment will keep initial operating expenses low and allows us to test out new locations at minimal cost while building market penetration.

In order to accomplish this pop-up model, we are seeking funding for the following initial investments:

  • $25,000 - Equipment purchase:  inflatable screen, mobile projector, speakers, FM transmitter, and more
  • $10,000 - Infrastructure: enclosed trailer and concession space
  • $15,000 - Start-up Capital: utilities, payroll, rent, and other expenses in initial months of operation

We look forward to your partnership in this venture and can't wait to create a local entertainment destination! Each and every contribution will bring us one step closer to our dream. In addition to knowing that you’re helping us make history in our town, we’ve set up a series of awesome perks as a just one more gesture of gratitude! THANK YOU for your contributions!

**If you need your items shipped, please select the shipped option when making your pledge. If not, we’ll take that as you’ll be coming in person to pick up your items. We will have all items ready for pickup before our grand opening! 

  • $15 - Personal Shout-Out On Social Media

  • $25 - Pen & Stationary Package

  • $50 - Custom Stainless Travel Mug

  • $100 - Roll-up Blanket

  • $250 - Complete Founders Club Package

Other Ways You Can Help

If a financial contribution isn’t in your budget right now, we could still use your help to spread the word about the Verde Drive-In!

  • Share our project on any social media platform
  • Tell your local friends and family about us!
  • Continue to follow along and join in the discussion. When we open come check us out and leave us a review on Facebook or Google.

And, of course, don't hesitate to contact us with any questions you may have. Thank you for your support!

$50 - Custom Stainless Travel Mug

$250 - Complete Founders Club Package
