And, of course, don't hesitate to contact us with any questions you may have. Thank you for your support!

story:
Come Forage With Us

My name is Hazzel.

I went to college for fashion design. Back then, my dream was to learn manufacturing and share my creations with the world. But after a few eye-opening years, I learned about how wasteful the industry was, and was determined to not be a part of the problem. Forager is the culmination of what I've learned, my childhood inspirations, and beyond. It combines my love of vintage clothes, entrepreneurial spirit, and hope to be a part of the solution to a wasteful industry.

A brick-and-mortar shop in my hometown of Beaverton, Forager will sell casual vintage clothing, accessories, homewares, as well as other small goods that contribute to an eclectic and mindful lifestyle. It will also stock art and accessories from local makers. Forager will bring a mindful, eclectic shopping experience that shares a beautiful selection of clothes and gifts, and drives traffic to Portland's up-and-coming neighbor. It will be a cozy and welcoming shop with photo-worthy displays that you will be excited to share. 

Forager will be opening in February or March 2020, in downtown Beaverton.

What we Need and Why

Our funding goal is $9.000.

I know we probably won't make this, but if we do that will be a dream come true. This will help us pay for initial renovations and and supplies so we can get the doors open!

In the beginning, I'm planning to keep the business afloat with loans and credit cards, but some extra funding from you guys will help keep risk down, and give me some extra leverage to start off on the right foot!

I'm turning to IndieGoGo because I want to make my dream a reality. I do not qualify for a low interest loan because of my student loan debts and lack of collateral. I do not have family with the capital to lend me. I have been saving all that I have been able to, and investing straight into my business. Other business owners have advised that now is the best time to get in and open shop in Beaverton. I didn't want to miss my chance!

The nitty gritty: Our total financial goal is $48,000, to comfortably keep our cash in the positive for the first year. This goal would allow Forager yo have three months of operating expenses at our lowest point, and allow us comfortable room for error. Forager has also qualified for a P2P loan of $30,000. We plan to also open an SBA Line of Credit with Columbia Bank, along with a business credit card, to spread out debts to the terms with the lowest interest rates.

 

The Impact

Downtown Beaverton has very few shopping options; a list of small shops that you can count on one hand, and a dozen big box retailers that have not been doing amazingly over the years. Local residents and commuters passing through have been asking for more unique options.

Although not world-changing, this boutique will be a great asset for a growing neighborhood. Forager will excitedly get involved with city events, with a dream to be a staple of the downtown center. Along with bringing a beautiful shop to downtown Beaverton, funding this project means  bringing my dream of a vintage boutique to reality. Not only will this create a lifetime job for me, it will hopefully open up the door to many others as the shop expands, bringing more possibilities into Beaverton as a whole.

Although it will need a bit to take off, I am projecting that Forager will be profitable by its first Holiday season, and only growing afterwards.

 

Risks & Challenges

Fortunately, I have experience in managing a retail shop, ordering supplies and inventory, marketing, design, and more. I am very confident in my abilities to run a shop as the sole owner, and finding talented stylists to cover the sales side of things. However, even with my experience, there are always risks.

The biggest risk to our business would be the unpredictability of initial sales, as one of the very few retail shops in downtown Beaverton. While we can't know for sure what our sales will be, to mitigate this as much as possible we will work closely with Impact Beaverton and financial experts to develop sales forecasts that make sense for the area. Once we are open, we will be adaptable and pivot our offerings quickly to fulfill what our customers are buying.

Another risk will be incomplete funding. If we lost any of our expected sources of funding, we may be able to get the doors open, but we may not be able to sustain our business expenses throughout the first year. Even if we decreases expenses, our rent expense will be non-negotiable. To mitigate this, we will shop around to make our funding options as thorough as possible, including loans, credit lines, and crowdfunding from friends & family. We will aim to reach our funding goal in cash and loans, but additional credit options will provide a safety cushion.

A smaller but very real risk is sudden injury or illness. Since Forager will be a Sole Proprietor LLC and the owner will be running most of the store operations, the business could fail if anything happens to the owner, even for a short time. To mitigate this, we will work with a business attorney to acquire recommended insurance policies early on. We will also aim to hire a team of reliable stylists as early as financially possible and train them on the backend operations of the shop, so that if anything terrible happens the shop can stay open.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, there are still other ways you can show your support!

Follow Forager Vintage on Social Media
Liking, commenting, and sharing content helps out way more than you think!

 https://www.instagram.com/forager_vintage/

 https://www.facebook.com/ForagerVintage/
 

Share the IndieGoGo Campaign
Share this around! Other Beaverton residents might be excited for the idea.

Help with the build-out!
If you are near Beaverton and willing to help me move in, let me know! I need manpower and trucks. No date is set yet, but it will be extremely helpful to know who I can call on! The more hands, the faster I can get the doors open.

Connect me with lenders
It's a stretch, but I might as well ask. I'm already working with banks, but if you know anyone personally who is willing to lend, I would be grateful long term loan options

 

 

Why Beaverton?

This type of shop is thriving in East Portland shopping districts, but out there is not as startup-friendly. Real estate is much more expensive, and competition is fierce. Not only is Beaverton a little easier to get into, it is also my hometown. I am excited to be a part of it as it expands, and bring a little more to the town I've spent most of my life in.

The City of Beaverton has been steadily expanding its efforts in the last few years as part of the Beaverton Downtown Design Project, with the vision to "create a vibrant downtown". They have been building out new spaces for retail, new apartments, and funding grants to improve existing structures and storefronts. With these development projects, frequent local events, and robust community support, there will be many more visitors coming through downtown. The city will also have many more resources available to share with small businesses, compared to previous years.

 

Why a Vintage Shop?

I have been really into thrifting since middleschool, finding much more unique options than I would ever find at a department store. But what really got me interested in vintage specifically, was working with a vintage boutique in downtown Portland for a few years. Their driving force was to waste as little fabric as possible, which was really inspiring. I learned a lot there, and gained a huge appreciation for vintage. Vintage clothing is both trendy and nostalgic. Each piece has a history, each a conversation starter and piece of wonder. It is sturdy and trustworthy, having lasted so long with other owners, unlike fast fashion that falls apart quickly. And each piece salvaged is one more piece out of the landfill, cutting down on waste and preserving history.

Economically, resale stores are also doing extremely well. If you haven't taken a walk through the shopping streets in East Portland, the numbers show it as well. According to a 2019 industry report by resale platform Thredup, the total secondhand apparel market is expected to double within the next 5 years. 64% of women are now willing to purchase secondhand products, and while many customers are moving away from department stores, 51% of consumers plan on increasing their spend on secondhand clothing this year over last. The secondhand market is thriving. It's where the market is, and great for the planet as well.

 

 

How can I stay updated?

I will be posting weekly updates to the campaign here, as well as occasional updates and marketing to social media. Please follow along!

Not only is Beaverton a little easier to get into, it is also my hometown. I am excited to be a part of it as it expands, and bring a little more to the town I've spent most of my life in.The City of Beaverton has been steadily expanding its efforts in the last few years as part of the Beaverton Downtown Design Project, with the vision to "create a vibrant downtown". They have been building out new spaces for retail, new apartments, and funding grants to improve existing structures and storefronts. With these development projects, frequent local events, and robust community support, there will be many more visitors coming through downtown. The city will also have many more resources available to share with small businesses, compared to previous years. Why a Vintage Shop?I have been really into thrifting since middleschool, finding much more unique options than I would ever find at a department store. But what really got me interested in vintage specifically, was working with a vintage boutique in downtown Portland for a few years. Their driving force was to waste as little fabric as possible, which was really inspiring. I learned a lot there, and gained a huge appreciation for vintage. Vintage clothing is both trendy and nostalgic. Each piece has a history, each a conversation starter and piece of wonder. It is sturdy and trustworthy, having lasted so long with other owners, unlike fast fashion that falls apart quickly. And each piece salvaged is one more piece out of the landfill, cutting down on waste and preserving history.Economically, resale stores are also doing extremely well. If you haven't taken a walk through the shopping streets in East Portland, the numbers show it as well. According to a 2019 industry report by resale platform Thredup, the total secondhand apparel market is expected to double within the next 5 years. 64% of women are now willing to purchase secondhand products, and while many customers are moving away from department stores, 51% of consumers plan on increasing their spend on secondhand clothing this year over last. The secondhand market is thriving. It's where the market is, and great for the planet as well.  How can I stay updated?I will be posting weekly updates to the campaign here, as well as occasional updates and marketing to social media. Please follow along!

story:
*** Per leggere la versione in italiano, scorri la pagina! ***

 

Read more about our project, Social Restaurant, and give us your support. You can donate or get a perk. To thank you for your contribution we have prepared many nice perks just for you. Grazie!

 

 

About us

 

The Cameli family has been managing the Vecchio Convento restaurant and hotel in Portico di Romagna and the Academy Olmo school of Italian language and cuisine for four generations.

A family of chefs and restaurateurs who believed in the development of the social and economic fabric of the Tuscan-Romagna Apennines and still believes in the revitalization of the area today by developing food and wine tourism and small local businesses.

Today the family business is run by the Massimiliano and Matteo brothers, two chefs who have always worked in the best kitchens in the world, especially in Northern Europe. Invited by internationally acclaimed chefs to play a leading role in theme nights, cooking shows, fairs, festivals, wine tastings and events, Massimiliano and Matteo never forget the origins and traditions of their homeland, Romagna-Tuscany.


 
What is the "Social Restaurant" Project?

And why is it "social"?

The "Social Restaurant"; project arises from the personal experiences of Massimiliano and Matteo who found firsthand, while visiting the Nordic countries, that "classic Italian" cuisine really is one of the most appreciated in the world, but at the same time the experience and professionalism necessary to produce it are not as widespread.

 The question arose spontaneously for Massimiliano: "Why not bring a little Italian style to Northern Europe?" Our plan is to export the most authentic Tuscan-Romagna culinary tradition to Denmark and to import business and know-how to Portico di Romagna and the surrounding area with the help of those who believe in this idea."

 

The business challenge is to create new lasting jobs and bring new investments into our area and other areas of the Tuscan-Romagna Apennines, as they are subject to a critical decrease in the population and consequent lack of economic sustainability of many projects.

We will therefore combine the artisan heart of the Romagnolo people with the typical business knowledge of Nordic countries, exploiting the passion for Italian cuisine and respect for nature and tradition as a link.

 

Social stands, above all, for "social sector", as a large part of the fundings from the Project will be used to support and (re)finance social and ethical projects and cultural schemes in Portico di Romagna and the surrounding area.

Massimiliano and Matteo have already successfully completed several social projects with a method they invented called "Cooking for Joy", which combines cooking with yoga and storytelling to "restore the soul of the most fragile people". For example:

  • the Cooking School in Prison in Forlì, both for women and men
  • the Cooking School in the Village of Joy of the "Papa Giovanni XXIII" Association of Forlì dedicated to people with social problems
  • Cooking Courses for non-EU people for the purposes of helping them to find employment.

But social stands also - and obviously - for "social networks" ... because we need your help to spread the project to all your friends and acquaintances, Italian and non-Italian, inviting them to participate in crowdfunding.

 

 
 

Targets

The "Social Restaurant" is a complex project that consists of several steps, each with a specific objective/purpose, which we will only be able to achieve if adequate funding levels are reached.

The goals are ambitious, but not unattainable. We will find part of the fundings with direct investments by private individuals, business people and local companies that believe in the rebirth of the Tuscan-Romagna Apennines ... but we also need your crowdfunding contribution!

 

Step 1: Osteria and Pizzeria in Odder (Denmark)

On reaching the first € 150,000 we will open an Osteria and Gourmet Pizzeria in Odder, Denmark, with an adjoining wine shop and retail and wholesale of typical products of Romagna. The culinary proposal will be "classic Italian" (from Romagna) and we will only use top quality ingredients from our area.
To help Massimiliano and Matteo in this great project, an international team of first-rate professionals (managers, chefs, bakers, and so on) from all over the world was set up.

 
Step 2: Bakery and Pastry in Portico di Romagna (Italy)

On reaching € 250,000, we will open a bakery and pastry shop in Portico di Romagna with a short supply chain of grain. Under the supervision of the Mulino Pransani company, we will plant ancient organic grains in collaboration with local farmers, to produce our flour and create income and new jobs in the Apennines (we estimate at least 10 jobs).
 
We will also dedicate a large space to pastry, where, as master pastry chefs, we will develop new recipes and new combinations starting from local products and raw materials.


Step 3: Restoration of the 17th century water mill in Portico di Romagna (Italy)

 

On reaching € 350,000, together with co-financing by the Emilia Romagna Region, we will be able to participate in the restoration of a 17th century water mill of great historical and cultural value.
This mill will enable us to produce flour in an artisanal way and particularly from ancient grains, creating new jobs and a greater fixed income for local farmers (we estimate at least 8 jobs).
 

 

Consultants

For the planning and implementation of this project we made use of an international team of professionals, from Italy and Denmark:

  • for projects in Northern Europe: Rasmus Lond (Denmark), Christina Brinks (Denmark), Soeil Safa (Denmark), Óli Hall (Iceland), Gunnar Hellsten (Sweden)
  • for the development of the website and digital communication: Librasoft and Kuma
  • video making and editing: Gianluca Donati e Gabriele Donati
  • for administration and consulting services: Franco Corzani, Nicola Corzani, Elisa Toni, Lars Larsen
  • for legal aspects: Avv .Marco Mini.

 

 
 

Contacts

For  anything you might need (generic or detailed info, questions about the project or the perks, and so on), you can visit the website www.socialrestaurantproject.com or send an email to info@socialrestaurantproject.com

Massimiliano and Matteo will gladly answer you back as soon as possible. You can also find us on Facebook "Social Restaurant Project".

 

 

*** versione in italiano ***

 

Scopri e sostieni il progetto Social Restaurant. Fai una donazione per supportare il nostro progetto. Per ringraziarti del tuo contributo, abbiamo preparato per te tanti premi esclusivi.

 

Chi Siamo

Siamo la Famiglia Cameli che da ben quattro generazioni gestisce a Portico di Romagna il ristorante e albergo diffuso Vecchio Convento e la scuola di cucina e lingua italiana Academy Olmo.

Una famiglia di cuochi e di ristoratori che hanno creduto nello sviluppo del tessuto sociale ed economico dell’Appennino Tosco-Romagnolo, e che ancora oggi credono nel rilancio della zona grazie al turismo enogastronomico e alla piccola imprenditoria locale.

Oggi il testimone è nelle mani di Massimiliano e Matteo: fratelli e chef che da sempre frequentano le migliori cucine del Mondo e, in particolare, del Nord Europa. Invitati da chef di caratura internazionale a partecipare come protagonisti in serate a tema, cooking show, fiere, festival, wine tasting ed eventi, Massimiliano e Matteo non dimenticano mai le origini e le tradizioni della loro terra: la Romagna-Toscana.

 

Cos’è il Progetto “Social Restaurant”?

E perché è “social”?

Il progetto “Social Restaurant” nasce dalle esperienze personali di Massimiliano e Matteo, che visitando i paesi nordici hanno constatato in prima persona che la cucina “classica italiana” è, per davvero, una delle più apprezzate del mondo, ma che allo stesso tempo l’esperienza e la professionalità per realizzarla non sono altrettanto diffuse.

A Massimiliano la domanda è sorta spontanea: “Perché non portare un po’ di italianità nel Nord Europa?”.

“Proviamo a esportare in Danimarca la tradizione culinaria tosco-romagnola più verace e a importare business e know-how a Portico di Romagna e dintorni, con l’aiuto di chi crede in questa idea.”

 

La sfida imprenditoriale è quella di creare nuovi posti di lavoro duraturi e portare nuovi investimenti nella nostra area e nelle altre aree dell’Appennino Tosco-Romagnolo, in quanto soggette a una decrescita critica della popolazione e conseguente insostenibilità economica di molti progetti.

Uniremo quindi il cuore artigiano dei Romagnoli alla conoscenza del business tipica dei paesi del nord, sfruttando come legante la passione per la cucina italiana e il rispetto della natura e della tradizione.

Social sta, soprattutto, per “sociale”, in quanto gran parte dei ricavati del Progetto sarà utilizzata per supportare e (ri)finanziare progetti sociali ed etici, iniziative culturali nell’area di Portico di Romagna e dintorni.

 

Massimiliano e Matteo hanno già portato a termine con successo diverse iniziative sociali con un metodo da loro inventato chiamato "Cooking for Joy", che unisce la cucina allo yoga e allo storytelling per "restaurare l'animo delle persone più fragili". Ad esempio:

  • la Scuola di Cucina in Carcere a Forlì, sia per le donne che per gli uomini
  • la Scuola di Cucina nel Villaggio della Gioia dell’Associazione Papa Giovanni XXIII di Forlì, dedicata alle persone con problemi sociali
  • i Corsi di Cucina per gli Extra Comunitari con finalità di inserimento nel mondo del lavoro.

 

Ma social sta anche -e ovviamente- per “social network”... perché abbiamo bisogno del tuo aiuto per diffondere l’iniziativa a tutti i tuoi amici e conoscenti, italiani e non, invitandoli a partecipare al crowdfunding.

 

 

Obiettivi

Il “Social Restaurant” è un progetto complesso che consta di diverse fasi, ciascuna con un obiettivo/scopo ben preciso, che potremo realizzare solo al raggiungimento di livelli di finanziamento adeguati.

 

Gli obiettivi sono ambiziosi, ma non irraggiungibili: troveremo parte delle coperture con investimenti diretti di privati, imprenditori e aziende locali che credono nella rinascita dell’Appennino Tosco-Romagnolo… ma abbiamo bisogno anche del tuo contributo di crowdfunding!

 

Step 1: Osteria e Pizzeria a Odder (Danimarca)

Al raggiungimento dei primi 150.000€ apriremo una Osteria e Pizzeria Gourmet a Odder, in Danimarca, con annesso wine shop e vendita al dettaglio e all’ingrosso di prodotti tipici romagnoli. La proposta culinaria sarà “classica italiana” (romagnola) e utilizzeremo solo ingredienti di prima qualità e provenienti dal nostro territorio.

Ad aiutare Massimiliano e Matteo in questo grande progetto è stata allestita una squadra internazionale di professionisti (manager, chef, fornai, ...) di prima grandezza e provenienti da tutte le parti del mondo.

 

Step 2: Forno e Pasticceria a Portico di Romagna (Italia)

Al raggiungimento dei 250.000€, realizzeremo un Forno e Pasticceria a Portico di Romagna, con filiera corta del grano. Con la supervisione dell’Azienda Mulino Pransani, pianteremo grani antichi biologici in collaborazione con i contadini locali, per produrre la nostra farina e creare reddito e nuovi posti di lavori nell’Appennino (stimiamo almeno 10 posti di lavoro).

Dedicheremo un ampio spazio anche alla pasticceria, dove in qualità di maestri pasticceri, svilupperemo nuove ricette e nuovi abbinamenti a partire dai prodotti e materia prima locale.

 

Step 3: Restauro Mulino ad Acqua del 1600 a Portico di Romagna (Italia)

Al raggiungimento dei 350.000€, unitamente al cofinanziamento da parte della Regione Emilia Romagna, potremo partecipare alla restauro di un Mulino ad acqua del 1600, di grande pregio storico e culturale.

Questo Mulino ci consentirà di produrre in modo artigianale la farina, in particolare quella di grani antichi, contribuendo con nuovi posti di lavoro e un maggiore reddito fisso per i contadini locali (stimiamo almeno 8 posti di lavoro).

 

Consulenti

Per la pianificazione e realizzazione di questo progetto ci siamo avvalsi di un team di professionisti internazionale, tra Italia e Danimarca:

  • per i progetti in Nord Europa: Rasmus Lond (Danimarca), Christina Brinks (Danimarca), Soeil Safa (Danimarca), Óli Hall (Islanda), Gunnar Hellsten (Svezia)
  • per lo sviluppo del sito web e della comunicazione digitale: Librasoft and Kuma
  • per il montaggio dei video: Gianluca Donati e Gabriele Donati
  • amministrativa e consulenziale: Franco Corzani, Nicola Corzani, Elisa Toni, Lars Larsen
  • per la parte legale: Avv. Marco Mini.

 

 

Contatti

Per ogni cosa (info dettagliate o generali, domande sul progetto, domande sui perk, ...), puoi visitare il sito www.socialrestaurantproject.com oppure mandare una mail a info@socialrestaurantproject.com

Massimiliano e Matteo saranno lieti di risponderti il prima possibile. Ci trovi anche su Facebook alla pagina "Social Restaurant Project".

story:
Freedom Lanes in Mountain Home, ID, is the only all-ages entertainment for miles - and thanks to COVID, it is in danger of closing. We want to keep it running - with your help.

-----

Freedom Lanes, a 16-lane bowling center, is a staple in Mountain Home, Idaho – Elmore County’s capital city. The center serves all the surrounding towns (about 28,000 people) and offers recreational opportunities to seniors, active duty military and veterans, students of all ages and the general public.  Some of the bowling center’s current senior league members started in that very house when they were juniors.  The center hosts Special Olympics events, charity and junior tournaments, and city competitions in addition to weekly leagues, and it was scheduled to host the 2021 State Championships before COVID came in and devastated communities and businesses alike. 

 

The current owner has talked about selling the center in the past, but things were running smoothly and business was consistent, so he decided to hold onto it.  The business took a distressing hit to the budget, however, when COVID first limited its capacity and then forced the doors closed in late March of 2020, and the owner struggled through several months of uncertainty until he was able to reopen.  Sadly, when the doors opened, some of his customers didn’t return and his league membership dropped – along with his employee roster.  He is now only open four days per week for roughly four hours at a time.  He counts on the winter revenue to carry him through the summer months, when he has little to no business due to the excellent outdoor activities in our beautiful state.  Sixteen hours of business per week isn’t going to give him what he needs to pay the bills.  Now he’s ready to sell.  If he doesn’t sell, the center may eventually close for good.  We don't know when, but we want to keep that from happening.

 

We want to continue to provide the people with somewhere to go where we can be together, listen to some music, laugh a little (or a lot), eat, bowl, catch up, and lean on each other.  The center gives the bowlers a sense of community, of belonging.  Despite the growth of Mountain Home and the increasing property values, the movie theater in town has already closed. The closest opportunity for indoor recreation and entertainment for all ages, aside from the military base which isn’t open to everyone, is nearly an hour away in each direction.  Unfortunately, with the vaccine just now being distributed and the future of COVID uncertain, banks are not anxious to lend money to businesses – especially entertainment businesses – right now.  And that’s where YOU come in.  We are trying some creative community-based financing to keep the center’s doors open.

 

  • For up to a $49 donation, you will have our eternal thanks and a shout-out on our website.
  • Between $50 and $149, you will have our eternal thanks, a website shout-out – and a window sticker to show your support.
  • For a $150-$249 donation, you’ll have all of the above, and your name on a permanent “Thank You” plaque in the bowling center.
  • Between $250 and $499, add free open bowling for a month to everything listed above.
  • For $500 to $999, we’ll include an entry into our first Pro Am tournament (TBD).
  • For donations of $1,000 or more, we’ll have to figure something out. 

 

**Please note that the "perks" offered in the windows to the right are not the only amounts you can donate - there should be a "Back it" button to donate any amount at the top of the page.  Any amount is welcomed and helpful, and we appreciate it all.**

 

Our lofty goal is $300,000 – that will give us the initial deposit, plus some funds to fix things that need to be fixed, update a few kitchen appliances, etc.  It’s a pretty daunting target, but all we need (a bit of sarcasm there) is 3,000 people to donate $100 and we’re golden (or 30,000 people to donate $10 – put in perspective, that’s about what most people spend at Starbucks for coffee and a muffin).  The target for this campaign is $60,000, but we hope to exceed that.  If, after all's said and done, we are unable to purchase the bowling center, we will turn around and donate whatever we raise online to the local Special Olympics chapter in Mountain Home.

 

If you would like to do some research, you’re welcome to look up our websites – this is a legit request, not a scam, we promise.  Our websites are http://freedomlanes.com and http://sidewinderstrikes.com.  And if you'd like to be an investor in the project, we do have a business plan for review - just contact us for that. Thanks for your consideration, and we hope to see you at Freedom Lanes in the not-so-distant future!

 

About Us

Matt and Lyn Bratton are bowlers who own Sidewinder Strikes Pro Shop inside Freedom Lanes.  We started the shop in Southern California several years ago and moved it up to Mountain Home in mid-2019, quickly getting to know the customers and the market.  Lyn has owned her own administrative consulting business for nearly two decades and has successfully spearheaded or significantly participated in several charitable campaigns, one of which is the subject of a recently published book, “Lauren’s Ride” by John Byrne.  Matt, a disabled veteran of the Air Force, has experience both on the bowler’s side, as Association Manager and holding pretty much every league board position, and on the house side, as General Manager of Sierra Lanes in Ridgecrest, CA.  When he was GM at Sierra, Matt implemented changes to personnel and operating procedures throughout the center, saving the bowling alley thousands of dollars during his tenure and helping to restore its reputation throughout the city.
 

 

We don’t work for the money.  We work for the love of the customers and the love of the sport – we love the sport so much that we got married at the National Bowling Stadium in Reno.  That’s why we want to purchase the bowling center.  We know the past and see the future of the sport, and we want to be here so the grandchildren of our bowlers will be able to enjoy it, too.

story:
Overview

Hi bush tea sippers! I am Simfoni Marie: educator, traveler, and avid reader "bahn and raised" in the Virgin Islands. I am the woman behind the Books 'n Bush Tea brand and, like many of you reading this, I also grew up in Dockside Bookshop: the popular bookstore that was a cornerstone in the Virgin Islands community since 1978. I, along with many Virgin Islanders, was DEVASTATED when Dockside Bookshop closed in 2013, taking the island's bookstore count from one to zero.

Now, I am on a mission to bring a homegrown bookstore back to the Virgin Islands, and I need your help. Join me in building a bookstore that will truly be a place to tell our own stories. A bookstore fo' deh culcha!

The Vision

Now more than ever, Virgin Islanders and Caribbean people alike, are desperately seeking a place to tell our own stories using our own voices. That's why, this fall, Books 'n Bush Tea will be opening as a mobile bookstore in the U.S. Virgin Islands. For my native Virgin Islanders, picture Dockside Bookshop, but compact and on wheels. A mobile bookstore will allow us to travel between the three islands (and maybe, even to other Caribbean islands) and bring books to areas with little access to them.

Books 'n Bush Tea will be the official bookstore of the U.S.  Virgin Islands. Our truck will be bursting at the seams with books by authors and illustrators from every corner of the Caribbean. In fact, every title on our shelves will be Caribbean-authored and/or Caribbean-illustrated. We will offer a curated selection of titles that will range from board books to novels to cookbooks, and everything in between. We will also offer dope Books 'n Bush Tea merch and book accessories. Oh, and don't forget the bush tea! All of the bush tea on our truck will be sourced from Caribbean-owned small businesses, of course.

It's time for us to show the world that the Caribbean experience is not a monolith. If you were raised on books 'n bush tea, or even if you weren't and just want to see our Caribbean community thrive as much as we do, I'm asking you to help us get to our goal of $125,000, which represents a fraction of Books 'n Bush Tea's total start-up budget. Every dollar we raise beyond our goal is a dollar that goes toward buying the building for our future brick-and-mortar location.

CHOOSE YOUR REWARD AND HELP US BRING A MOBILE BOOKSTORE TO THE VIRGIN ISLANDS! >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

 

HOW MUCH DOES IT COST TO OPEN A BOOKSTORE "FO' DEH CULCHA"?

It turns out bookstores are pretty expensive. But, not as expensive as an entire generation of children growing up without knowledge of self. Let that sink in, then keep reading. While my personal investment will take us some of the way, I still need your help to customize the truck, purchase opening inventory and our point-of-sale inventory management system, and to get the truck home to the Virgin Islands. Books 'n Bush Tea is not my bookstore; it is OUR bookstore. For the sake of transparency, I want you to know how your contribution will help us bring a homegrown bookstore to the Virgin Islands.

The Break Down

  • Purchase, Renovation, and Restructure of an 18' Diesel Step Van: This includes restructuring the entire vehicle, structuring the roof and brace for ac install, running electrical amp service, fabricating the bookshelves, fabricating the seating area, installing flooring, mounting the generator, etc. = $53,000

  • Books & Non-Book Merchandise = $55,000 Once the truck is built, we'll need to fill it from top to bottom with all things Caribbean lit!

  • Point-of-Sale/Inventory Management System = $7,500

  • Cost of Shipping the Truck to the Virgin Islands = $3,000

  • Mobile Vendor Licenses/Permits/Insurance = $6,500

  • Indiegogo Fees = Indiegogo deserves their cut for bringing us together = 5% of funds raised + 30 cents per contribution (includes platform and credit card fees) + cost of perks + cost to ship your perks to you (shipping is included in the perk cost).

Spread the word!

A project like ours depends on word of mouth! Use Indiegogo’s share tools, use the hashtag #ahomegrownbookstore and tag us!

Follow us on social media: We're @booksnbushtea on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Don't forget to share the story with your friends and family!

 

Thank You!

Thank you from the Books 'n Bush Tea Team! With your support, we will make Books 'n Bush Tea a household name for generations to come. Most importantly, we cannot wait for you to join us at the Books 'n Bush Tea book truck when we open in the fall of 2021!

story:
6000+ years of trading, business and culture...

Aniin (Hello!) my name is Tara Everett and I'm and Anishinaabe Innovator, Motivator and Entrepreneur and proud Founder and CEO of Canoe Coworking Inc.

A passionate helper my path started in Business Administration, Career Development and Program Coordination. When I lost my job suddenly I missed having a community in which to do good work - a home office wasn't cutting it anymore and like many freelancers my mental health was taking a toll. When I looked for a space that reflected my cultural and traditional values and didn't find one I was gifted with the idea for Canoe Coworking Inc.

What started as a desire for a place to gather to do work blossomed into an International movement to empower Indigenous peoples in business to collaborate and help each other grow. The approach to Canoe we are taking is holistic and includes making spiritual, cultural and health a core focus to our success as business owners and original stewards of the land.

Winnipeg, Manitoba has one of the highest concentrations of Urban Indigenous people in Canada but our businesses are scattered and programs are a patchwork quilt to access. Canoe intends to provide the space, members so we can partner with experts to help our community grow to new heights. 

What We Need

We're reaching for the stars to get the funding we need. Here's how you can expect it to go:

Immediate Bills - These are professionals and we needed their help!:

  • $1,500 - Accountant (Because we legally have to file taxes...)
  • $1,000 - Architect (Floor plans, Site Feasibility) 
  • $550 - Lawyer (Set up LLC, Negotiated a lease with terms that saved me.)

Deposit & 3 Months Rent

  • $15,000 (We are looking at roughly 3,000 sq/ft outside of downtown Winnipeg)

Leasehold Improvement & Furniture

  • Keeping it simple by furnishing our guests with their immediate needs like desks, seating, technology and making our space accessible for all.

What if you go over your goal?

Anything over and above our goals goes towards core operating funds including additional building/renovations, base salary for Tara and marketing costs.

What You Get

Our perks are all unique like our supporters. Each perk includes a personal message to all backers in the form of a video that will be permanently posted to our website.

Each dollar will be accounted for and regular updates through Indiegogo and our social media sites mean you can follow your contribution and see the impact it makes. 

The Impact

Canoe Coworking Inc. is one of less then five Indigenous coworking spaces worldwide.

An investment or contribution to our space will leave a lasting legacy. You are supporting a community of business owners who are driven to be collaborative and community focused.

For our investors this Indiegogo campaign is helping create proof of concept which will enable us to access additional funds and programs.

We promise to create a report showing the social return on investment our space provides within three years time because business isn't all about money - it's about community.

Challenges

Space & Structure

Our space is will be accommodating a dynamic community - when we find the right one. To help us with this cornerstone challenge we've enlisted a professional real estate agent and reached out to our allies to find the right space in Winnipeg that will be open to a ceremony space, accessible, flexible and central to our clients needs in the big city.

With a space secured we be building our space from the ground up. Putting together the foundation of a space includes amenities like an Elders Lounge, kitchen and technology are put in place with the flow to encourage networking, collaborating and getting work done. We have several experts at the ready to help us when we reach this phase and Tara has a particular eye for detail and design.

Memberships

We're already building our pre-membership list including a top secret cornerstone tenant. 

We will be hosting events, open houses and membership drives locally so that when people hear we're about to drop anchor and open there will be a line around the block ready to rush in!

New Business Owner

We have a fantastic list of supporters, mentors and business greats ready to help us learn.

Even better we are ready, willing and able to listen to make Canoe a success. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you have talents or ideas you wish to share? It takes a village so fill out this form 

Since we're all about community we invite you to join ours and share. It really does help.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/canoecoworking/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/canoewpg
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/canoecoworkingwpg/
Web: https://www.canoecoworking.ca/

Press: 

 AllWork: https://bit.ly/2Fnaoh2

Shareable: https://bit.ly/2W3EyM2

European Coworking Assembly: https://bit.ly/2Y5djm0

SET for Success with Richard Lannon: https://bit.ly/2JopJlB

story:
Summary

Combining a life long love of coffee and the talent to make it well, Chloe So Hyun No and James Anderson first began planning a coffee business at our English language school in Seoul, South Korea.  It has been a shared dream of ours to own and work in our own coffee operation for years, and this campaign marks the final step towards actualizing this dream.

Though I have worked for years as an English teacher in South Korea, a job I loved dearly, making coffee drinks has always been among my greatest passions in life.  Equal parts science and intuition, there is a certain zen to creating drinks that is difficult for me to find in other activities.  Nothing makes me happier than handing someone their drink and watching them share an inward smile before they take a sip.

My partner, Chloe So Hyun No, is a fellow coffee aficionado and a consummate and unapologetic fan of the creation and consumption of snacks.  A talented baker and cook, she practices her craft every weekend, seeking out instruction from the best that Seoul has to offer to hone her skills and make connections.  She has a keen mind for business and self-improvement and is the "feet on the ground" to my "head in the clouds."

We are creating this business because we have faith in our abilities and believe in our vision.  We are almost there, and now we are endlessly thankful that we have people to help us across the finish line. 

Your contribution means everything to us.  It could help provide for part of our new espresso machine or coffee pot, upfit and design on our van, or even something small but vital like cup sleeves or napkins.

We have made something really neat here.  We hope that you are as excited as we are to be a part of it.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for help reaching our goal of $30,000 by early August. 

These contributions will help us put the finishing touches on our van, equipment and inventory.

The breakdown of the distribution of these funds is fairly even.

  • $10,000 will go towards work on the van
    • Design
    • Painting
    • Maintenance and upfit
  • $10,000 will go towards equipment.
    • Espresso machine
    • Espresso grinders
    • Coffee grinders
    • Ice machine
    • POS machine
  • $5,000 inventory
    • Coffee
    • Cups
    • Paper products
    • Milk
    • Assorted Ingredients
  • $5,000 miscellaneous expenses
    • Fuel
    • Legal fees
    • City fees
    • Commissary fees

We have elected to organize this campaign around "flexible funding," meaning that even if we weren't to reach our goal, we would keep the amount that we have raised.  So please remember that any amount helps us greatly!

Perks:

Now don't worry, we wouldn't send you home empty handed!  Exclusive merchandise designed by yours truly as well as catered events await you!  We have organized a tiered perk system based on the amount of the contribution:

$20: A set of specially made stickers

$100: THE CORNER dog logo T-shirt plus stickers

$500: Specially made THE CORNER tumbler plus T-shirt and stickers

$1000: Exclusive THE CORNER logo hoodie plus tumbler, T-shirt, and stickers.

$2500: a four hour long catered event plus merchandise (Limited to NC, SC, GA, VA, TN)

$5,000: Twelve hour long catered event plus merchandise (anywhere east of the Mississippi)

$10,000: a Two day catered event plus merchandise (anywhere in the lower 48 states!)

Think of these perks as a token of our appreciation for being a part of our vision.  We are endlessly grateful for any and all contributions, and please know that it truly goes a long way.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Look, we all know that not everyone who reads this will be able to contribute, and that is perfectly fine!  No one is beholden to us or our business, so if you find yourself unable to make a contribution, please know that we love you no matter what!

If however, you might be willing to help us in other ways, such as by sharing our campaign on social media or pleading our case to someone who might be interested in contributing, we would be grateful beyond measure.

 

Thanks to all who have visited here.  We appreciate your time and your attention and hope that you will remember this fondly when you see THE CORNER van rolling through town, bringing the people their coffee.
story_txt:
Summary
Combining a life long love of coffee and the talent to make it well, Chloe So Hyun No and James Anderson first began planning a coffee business at our English language school in Seoul, South Korea.  It has been a shared dream of ours to own and work in our own coffee operation for years, and this campaign marks the final step towards actualizing this dream.
Though I have worked for years as an English teacher in South Korea, a job I loved dearly, making coffee drinks has always been among my greatest passions in life.  Equal parts science and intuition, there is a certain zen to creating drinks that is difficult for me to find in other activities.  Nothing makes me happier than handing someone their drink and watching them share an inward smile before they take a sip.
My partner, Chloe So Hyun No, is a fellow coffee aficionado and a consummate and unapologetic fan of the creation and consumption of snacks.  A talented baker and cook, she practices her craft every weekend, seeking out instruction from the best that Seoul has to offer to hone her skills and make connections.  She has a keen mind for business and self-improvement and is the "feet on the ground" to my "head in the clouds."
We are creating this business because we have faith in our abilities and believe in our vision.  We are almost there, and now we are endlessly thankful that we have people to help us across the finish line. 
Your contribution means everything to us.  It could help provide for part of our new espresso machine or coffee pot, upfit and design on our van, or even something small but vital like cup sleeves or napkins.
We have made something really neat here.  We hope that you are as excited as we are to be a part of it.

What We Need & What You Get
We are asking for help reaching our goal of $30,000 by early August. 
These contributions will help us put the finishing touches on our van, equipment and inventory.
The breakdown of the distribution of these funds is fairly even.

$10,000 will go towards work on the van
Design
Painting
Maintenance and upfit


$10,000 will go towards equipment.
Espresso machine
Espresso grinders
Coffee grinders
Ice machine
POS machine


$5,000 inventory
Coffee
Cups
Paper products
Milk
Assorted Ingredients


$5,000 miscellaneous expenses
Fuel
Legal fees
City fees
Commissary fees



We have elected to organize this campaign around "flexible funding," meaning that even if we weren't to reach our goal, we would keep the amount that we have raised.  So please remember that any amount helps us greatly!

story:
Overview

Two years ago, during the summer of 2017, we decided to expand into a full-service café/bakery. We found the PERFECT location in Virgil Village, just a few minutes away from our studio in Los Feliz. However, opening a full-service bakery has turned out to be far more challenging than we EVER imagined. Over the last two years, we’ve dealt with countless construction and permitting delays that have pushed back the opening date while draining our funds.

We're closer than ever to finishing with about 4 weeks of work left but no longer have the capital to continue construction. Every month we’re paying two rents, storage fees, insurance, and loan paybacks. We need your support to get across the finish line, and finally, open the doors to a warm neighborhood space where everyone can gather and make memories over coffee and cake! 

Our Story

Butter Cake Shoppe was started in 2009 by me, Sasha Gustafson, as a fun side-project to allow me to experiment with fun decorating techniques using fondant, gum paste, and tons of other new and exciting ways of hand-crafting celebration cakes while I worked another full-time job at a local bakery.

I started by posting ads on Craigslist and had customers pick up their orders in the living room of my one-bedroom apartment. To my surprise, my apartment-based cake shoppe was really taking off! But as demand for my cakes grew, it became clear that I had to make a difficult choice – continue working my dependable full-time job or take the risk and try to grow my own creative outlet into my full-time gig. Well, I decided to take the risk – to quit my job and move the cake shoppe into a small cake studio in my neighborhood of Los Feliz.

In order for me to focus on baking and decorating, I brought in my lovely sister, Ariadna, to help with customers, taking orders, and holding personalized cake tastings. This is where the super-star team of Sasha and Ari that you all know so well was born and when BUTTER became a family-owned business.

Since we first opened the small cake studio, we have taken BUTTER from awkward living room pickups to the well-oiled baking and decorating machine that it is now – balancing out-the-door offerings, custom-decorated cakes, and top-notch customer service. We have helped craft treats for everything from birthdays to bat mitzvahs to weddings, anniversaries, and even divorce parties! 

Customer Feedback

Our hard work in the cake studio has allowed us to build a loyal base of customers, earning us 5 stars on Yelp with over 250 reviews! As the number of rave reviews has increased, so has the demand for our creative cakes, and we just can’t fit enough equipment in the small studio to meet this demand.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re asking you to make an investment in us to help with our $40,425 goal, so that we can open the doors and start baking out of our new shoppe. The benefit to you is in the form of awesome perks including custom cakes, cupcakes, tasty treats, gift cards, coffee and an amazing new place to gather! We’re also offering a very special workshop for those who want to learn how to make sugar flowers with us! 

(Below are the construction photos)

Your donations will go towards material and labor to be performed:

  • Complete and verify all electrical and wiring
  • Label all breakers
  • Finish installing tile in the bathroom walls and grout
  • Finish installing all sinks, faucets, vanities, double oven, metro shelves,
  • Install Refrigerator
  • Epoxy entire floor
  • Install countertops for the cabinets
  • Cabinets and shelving 
  • Install cement boards 
  • Tile for the front of the cabinets
  • Install all doors
  • Finish walk-in fridge
  • Storefront
  • Finish Paint
  • Install lighting fixtures

Total we need to raise: $40,425

We've put everything we have into this because we believe WITHOUT A DOUBT THAT WE'RE GOING TO ROCK IT! You can help us prove it by donating or grabbing some of our cool perks today!

If we exceed our goal...

Our plan is to use the extra money to get a few more pieces of furniture for additional seating, create some cool merch, add more items to the kid's corner, and make Butter an amazing place to be at.

Our Community Pledge

Giving back to the community that has shown us endless love and support throughout this journey is essential to us. We look forward to participating in Virgil Village's First Fridays (a monthly neighborhood fundraiser in support of Lockwood Elementary). We will also be joining Master of Taste for the 3rd year, helping raise funds for Union Station Homeless Services. 

During the last 5 years, we've been able to show our support to local schools including Los Angeles Lycee International, Micheltorena, Franklin and Ivanhoe Elementary and organizations such as LA Breast Cancer Foundation, CHLA's St Baldrick's Head Shave Event, and Fit Foodie 5K Marathon in support of No Kid Hungry. We are excited to continue our efforts and impacting our local community in positive ways. 

The Impact

One great thing about our tiny shoppe is that it puts us in direct and intimate contact with our community. People walk by and see us through the window, and they can see how hard we work and how much love goes into everything we create.

We wanted to keep that connection, so we designed the new space with a massive window into the kitchen so that everyone can continue to see us at work. We want to share the beauty and creativity of what we do with them, and invite them into our world.

Close to my heart, personally, is the fact that our new location will have a kid's space for me to bring my new baby to the bakery. With help from family, I will be able to be with my newborn while continuing to work, be creative, and fulfill my ambitions. As a woman business owner, this is SO important to me. 

 

We Need Your Help To Finish

We are also excited to be able to have space for a regular schedule of workshops and events to share what we do with others. We are planning to offer evening and weekend classes on fun things like perfecting pie crusts, decorating with fondant, and crafting sugar flowers. We are thrilled at the prospect of bringing groups of adventurous and creative neighbors together to learn and have fun!

Butter Cake Shoppe has hand-crafted the centerpieces of countless celebrations throughout Los Angeles from our tiny cake studio in Los Feliz, allowing us to get to know our neighborhood and build a giant family of loyal customers, but the small size has limited our ability to fully meet the demand of our community. This new location will allow us to continue serving the same great community that we have grown to love while providing many of the features that our customers have asked for – plenty of seating, a large and consistent selection of your favorite treats, and a specialty coffee program. 

Risks & Challenges

Of course, with any business venture, there are a lot of scary questions and challenges ahead. Will the new neighborhood welcome us with open arms? How do we afford a bigger team? Will customers love our coffee? Is our product great enough to keep us growing for years to come? And of course, the question that keeps me up at night - how do I juggle a business with my newborn baby? 

As a business owner and entrepreneur, the learning never stops. Having spent the last 11 years as a home baker, I can tell you with 100% confidence that our cakes and treats are some of the best out there. Year over year, we've increased revenue, and our customer base has grown. Our online reviews are consistently positive and helpful, and we've been featured in magazines, including Eastsider, VoyageLA, Eater LA, The Knot, and several more. As the cake decorator at BUTTER, I've been featured on Buzzfeed showing off my buttercream skills, and more recently, on Food Network's Christmas Cookie Challenge. We promise that with this new shoppe we will work tirelessly to bring you and the community the best bakery experience every single day!

As for running a business while being a full-time mom? I am grateful to have a business where I can apply my creativity and bake my heart out. I also get to work alongside my beautiful sister, and very soon, with my son by my side. Through the kitchen glass, you'll be able to follow our journey every step of the way!

Other Ways You Can Help

We cannot express enough how grateful we are to be a part of such an amazing community and for all of the support we have received to get us to where we are today.

Please help us reach our goals by:

  • Sharing our story with your friends and families
  • Sharing on your social media platforms 

We truly believe that together, with your support, we can finally open our brand new doors and continue this family business journey! 

Thank you for taking the time to check out our dream + indiegogo campaign - We hope to seat you soon! 

~ Sasha and Ari

story:
The Who, The What, The Where & The Why:

Nestled between the vibrant Highlandtown Arts District and historic row homes of Brewers Hill & Canton, you’ll soon find Baltimore’s newest (and coziest) community comic shop & bookstore! This area of Southeast Baltimore, though home to nearly fifty thousand residents, has been without a bookstore. In fact, there are no bookstores OR comic shops in the entire 21224 region, with the nearest comic shop a 45-minute bus ride away!

Like many folks, Dreamers & Make-Believers owner Miranda Nordell turned to books during the pandemic. But, with the library closed and no bookstores within easy reach, this proved more difficult than expected. After a year of difficulty accessing new books, and discovering that even without a pandemic, things like middle-grade graphic novels were hard to come by in Baltimore, Miranda decided this just wouldn’t do! If you can’t find what you’re looking for, it might be time to build it yourself.

This wasn’t a sudden dream, however, as, prior to relocating to Baltimore, Miranda managed a set of world-renowned comic book stores on the west coast. As the general manager for two comic book stores in Northern California, Miranda became deeply enmeshed in the world of comics and graphic novels. Not only did Miranda hone her skills of recommending the perfect read, but she also developed programs for the community, partnered with local teachers and librarians, and built relationships with comic creators around the world! Since 2017, Miranda has also run the social media account “Femme Power Comix”, which promotes feminist stories in comics, literature, pop culture and beyond.

On a more personal note, Miranda’s deep love of comics comes from discovering the medium at a unique and important time. After a traumatic incident, Miranda found herself watching Netflix’s Jessica Jones, and was surprised to see similarities between the fictional character’s expressions of trauma and her own. Though Miranda had never read a comic book before, she felt drawn to her local shop in hopes of discovering more information on this flawed hero. What she found was a world of them! Comic books like Jessica Jones and She-Hulk were more than stories, they were the beginning of a fictional support group full of similarly flawed women also trying to crawl up from a dark place. MIranda never expected the medium of comics to have such a profound impact, or to serve as a catalyst for empowerment and growth, but since that time, Miranda has dreamed of helping others know comic books and graphic novels in that same way.

When a Brewers Hill doctor’s office that had been vacant for nearly a decade became available for lease, it only took one visit before Miranda knew it would be the perfect place to house her dream of a neighborhood bookstore. A place that spent decades helping Southeast Baltimore heal will continue that tradition, only now through the transformative (and healing) power of books!

Miranda’s plan is to create a warm & welcoming place where the community can go for reading recommendations, and where the curious, casual newcomer and veteran comic book aficionado alike will feel confident that the shop will reflect and meet their literary needs. Unfortunately, comic book spaces are notorious for making customers feel as though a high-barrier of knowledge is required for entry; Miranda rejects the notion of “gate-keeping”, and is incredibly committed to creating a place that feels approachable and user-friendly for everyone.

Dreamers & Make-Believers will offer a diverse array of books, but will specialize in graphic novels, with a particular focus on stories written and illustrated by women, members of the queer community, and BIPOC. The shelves will be stocked with books and comics for the Dreamer of every age- from board & picture books to young adult and adult stories. Dreamers & Make-Believers will also have thousands of periodical comic books for sale, as well as fun gifts and goodies like enamel pins, t-shirts, and even tarot cards!

 

How You Can Help:

Miranda is so excited to breathe new life into this long vacant neighborhood doctor’s office! She and her husband knew as soon as they walked into this space, that it was a place where people came to be helped and to feel better, but turning exam rooms into a bookstore will require some creative renovations. Between permit fees, contractors, tool rentals, and demolition (to tear down walls, replace the floors and lighting, and install heating and cooling), they will need $20,000. They have carefully calculated these costs and added a small cushion for any associated surprises that often come with construction projects.

To fit out the store, they will need bookshelves, displays, a sales counter, and comfy seating for reading. There is a budget of $6,000 for these fixtures.

With a planned 54 shelves in the store for middle grade, young adult, and adult books, they will need funding to purchase at least 2,200 titles. When adding in the children’s book displays and back stock, they will need to purchase approximately 4,000 books, plus associated fun merchandise goodies, bringing the total to $28,000 for full inventory.

They will also have business-related costs, including a register and point of sale system, store signage, and a security system, with a budget of $6,000.

Recognizing that it often takes time to launch a new business, any additional funds will help them to set aside a nest egg for rent, utilities, future stock purchases, events, and marketing costs.

All in all, Miranda is hoping this amazing community can help her to raise at least $60,000.

 

Challenges & Goals:

Miranda realizes that the past year has been extremely challenging, particularly for small businesses.  And, yet, if there is one thing that we learned from this past year it’s how important the independent store owner is to the overall wellbeing of our community.  We also learned how important it is to be there for one another, whether on the other end of the phone, other side of a computer screen, or in the pages of a book. A good book can provide a safe place for you to both lose yourself and find yourself, and to imagine that there is more to life than you can actually see. To be able to provide a safe and welcoming place and a community resource that nurtures and fosters literacy, self-discovery, and self-confidence is not just Miranda’s dream, but her goal.  It is her plan to help others discover their voices.

Collaborating with other local businesses and joining a strong, cohesive merchants’ alliance will benefit not just the different business owners, but the community as a whole.

 

Perks:

The first 25 people to back at any perk level $25 and up are the inaugural members of our V.I.D. program (Very Important Dreamers) with special early access to sales, reserving spots at events etc. Plus 25% off your first purchase with us.

We are excited to offer a variety of goodies featuring our store logo, beautifully designed by illustrator Emma Munger! Levels include wearables for the whole family, from baby onesies and toddler tees, to adult sweatshirts and baseball tees! Every perk tier (from $5 on) includes either a handmade button, a 4x2” sticker, a custom bookmark, a tote bag, a mug, or all of the above! With some of the mug packs (like the “Books & Brew” tier), you will also find included a 1/4lb bag of coffee from Baltimore’s own High Grounds Coffee Roasters!

We are also thankful to partner with two amazing illustrators to offer some special items- the first, is Andrew Brozyna of Rather Keen for his Book Shop Enamel Pin, and the second is the talented Emma Munger offering a custom art piece (her Thelma & Louise art can be seen in the bottom row next to Andrew’s pin)!

If you’re looking to add your own touch to this new community space, you will also find some “big ticket” items including dedicating the reading corner and designing our Little Free Library!

You can check out the full collection of offerings on the right hand side of the page.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't support us financially, that's ok! We ask that you Spread The Word and share our campaign by following us on social media and sharing the story with your community!

Facebook: @dreamersbmore
Instagram: @dreamersbmore
Twitter: @dreamersbmore
TikTok: @dreamersbmore

 

Thank You!

We can’t wait for you to come visit, whether to shop, join a zine making workshop, or even just to discuss a shared love of Mariko Tamaki or Tillie Walden! Thank you for helping to make this dream a reality and create a welcoming community space to help nurture self-exploration through literacy in Southeast Baltimore!

Though Miranda had never read a comic book before, she felt drawn to her local shop in hopes of discovering more information on this flawed hero. What she found was a world of them! Comic books like Jessica Jones and She-Hulk were more than stories, they were the beginning of a fictional support group full of similarly flawed women also trying to crawl up from a dark place. MIranda never expected the medium of comics to have such a profound impact, or to serve as a catalyst for empowerment and growth, but since that time, Miranda has dreamed of helping others know comic books and graphic novels in that same way.When a Brewers Hill doctor’s office that had been vacant for nearly a decade became available for lease, it only took one visit before Miranda knew it would be the perfect place to house her dream of a neighborhood bookstore. A place that spent decades helping Southeast Baltimore heal will continue that tradition, only now through the transformative (and healing) power of books!Miranda’s plan is to create a warm & welcoming place where the community can go for reading recommendations, and where the curious, casual newcomer and veteran comic book aficionado alike will feel confident that the shop will reflect and meet their literary needs. Unfortunately, comic book spaces are notorious for making customers feel as though a high-barrier of knowledge is required for entry; Miranda rejects the notion of “gate-keeping”, and is incredibly committed to creating a place that feels approachable and user-friendly for everyone.Dreamers & Make-Believers will offer a diverse array of books, but will specialize in graphic novels, with a particular focus on stories written and illustrated by women, members of the queer community, and BIPOC. The shelves will be stocked with books and comics for the Dreamer of every age- from board & picture books to young adult and adult stories. Dreamers & Make-Believers will also have thousands of periodical comic books for sale, as well as fun gifts and goodies like enamel pins, t-shirts, and even tarot cards! How You Can Help:Miranda is so excited to breathe new life into this long vacant neighborhood doctor’s office! She and her husband knew as soon as they walked into this space, that it was a place where people came to be helped and to feel better, but turning exam rooms into a bookstore will require some creative renovations. Between permit fees, contractors, tool rentals, and demolition (to tear down walls, replace the floors and lighting, and install heating and cooling), they will need $20,000. They have carefully calculated these costs and added a small cushion for any associated surprises that often come with construction projects.To fit out the store, they will need bookshelves, displays, a sales counter, and comfy seating for reading. There is a budget of $6,000 for these fixtures.With a planned 54 shelves in the store for middle grade, young adult, and adult books, they will need funding to purchase at least 2,200 titles. When adding in the children’s book displays and back stock, they will need to purchase approximately 4,000 books, plus associated fun merchandise goodies, bringing the total to $28,000 for full inventory.They will also have business-related costs, including a register and point of sale system, store signage, and a security system, with a budget of $6,000.Recognizing that it often takes time to launch a new business, any additional funds will help them to set aside a nest egg for rent, utilities, future stock purchases, events, and marketing costs.All in all, Miranda is hoping this amazing community can help her to raise at least $60,000. Challenges & Goals:Miranda realizes that the past year has been extremely challenging, particularly for small businesses.  And, yet, if there is one thing that we learned from this past year it’s how important the independent store owner is to the overall wellbeing of our community.  We also learned how important it is to be there for one another, whether on the other end of the phone, other side of a computer screen, or in the pages of a book. A good book can provide a safe place for you to both lose yourself and find yourself, and to imagine that there is more to life than you can actually see. To be able to provide a safe and welcoming place and a community resource that nurtures and fosters literacy, self-discovery, and self-confidence is not just Miranda’s dream, but her goal.  It is her plan to help others discover their voices.Collaborating with other local businesses and joining a strong, cohesive merchants’ alliance will benefit not just the different business owners, but the community as a whole. Perks:The first 25 people to back at any perk level $25 and up are the inaugural members of our V.I.D. program (Very Important Dreamers) with special early access to sales, reserving spots at events etc. Plus 25% off your first purchase with us.We are excited to offer a variety of goodies featuring our store logo, beautifully designed by illustrator Emma Munger! Levels include wearables for the whole family, from baby onesies and toddler tees, to adult sweatshirts and baseball tees! Every perk tier (from $5 on) includes either a handmade button, a 4x2” sticker, a custom bookmark, a tote bag, a mug, or all of the above! With some of the mug packs (like the “Books & Brew” tier), you will also find included a 1/4lb bag of coffee from Baltimore’s own High Grounds Coffee Roasters!We are also thankful to partner with two amazing illustrators to offer some special items- the first, is Andrew Brozyna of Rather Keen for his Book Shop Enamel Pin, and the second is the talented Emma Munger offering a custom art piece (her Thelma & Louise art can be seen in the bottom row next to Andrew’s pin)!If you’re looking to add your own touch to this new community space, you will also find some “big ticket” items including dedicating the reading corner and designing our Little Free Library!You can check out the full collection of offerings on the right hand side of the page.    Other Ways You Can Help:If you can't support us financially, that's ok! We ask that you Spread The Word and share our campaign by following us on social media and sharing the story with your community!Facebook: @dreamersbmoreInstagram: @dreamersbmoreTwitter: @dreamersbmoreTikTok: @dreamersbmore Thank You!We can’t wait for you to come visit, whether to shop, join a zine making workshop, or even just to discuss a shared love of Mariko Tamaki or Tillie Walden! Thank you for helping to make this dream a reality and create a welcoming community space to help nurture self-exploration through literacy in Southeast Baltimore!

story:
Aldea is a community development organization that started as a non-profit in La Union, Honduras in 2009. In West Michigan we currently have a coffee roastery in Muskegon Heights and our first cafe in Grand Haven. Our mission is to bring quality and value to all that we craft and to make every interaction positive and authentic.  

We love what is happening in Muskegon and can’t wait to be a part of it. This area holds significant history for nearly every member of our team. The very first cup of coffee that Aldea served was at the Muskegon Farmer’s Market nearly a decade ago, and our time there gave us the confidence to pursue our first permanent retail location in 2015. The Pine Street cafe is a way for us to express ourselves by having a space that is solely ours. It also gives us the opportunity to build on our current offerings of high quality coffee and tea. For the very first time, we will be offering light food and baked items from our very own ovens.

Our goal is to raise $20,000 for the build-out and execution of our new cafe on Pine Street. Contributions will go directly to purchasing equipment and making this space warm and welcoming. Our new space will be bright, full of positive energy, and plants, lots of plants.

We are determined and honored to have this opportunity in Muskegon and will continue to pursue the project.

In 2015, Aldea Coffee began its first cafe inside the The Armory in downtown Grand Haven, MI. Throughout our first years there we witnessed friendships built, while growing our personal community as well. The community we have watched you all build is why we want to replicate this in another community, while giving you a new space to enjoy in a neighboring town.

Together,

through all we craft,

we emphasize quality and value in every interaction.

We believe the earth to be an inspiring place,

and we empower each other

to explore, enjoy, and preserve it.

You know and trust us because of our belief in bringing transparency to everything. We show you our values every day in how we run our business as well as live our personal lives. If you have a question about why we’re doing something, just ask. We will always be open with you about why we choose to do the things the way we do.

As a company striving to receive our B Corp Certification, while simultaneously working to become zero-waste, we are hoping to lead by example and bring others along on the journey to preserve the Earth. We will continue to bring well-being to you and the Earth by using mindful business practices and serving intentionally sourced food and beverages.



Thank you for contributing to our new location! We're so glad you're a part of our community!

story:
Summary

Have you ever truly wondered how Moms and Dads travel with 1 Baby, 2, 3, or even 4?  They struggle to drag luggage and Baby Gear like Car Seats, Strollers or Pack and Plays without losing their patience and their minds.  When you travel with a baby or toddler, traveling light is but a distant dream. Lugging Double Strollers, Pack and Plays, Toys, Car Seats and more will not only slow you down but weigh you down and now-a-days cost you significantly more with the exuberant airport fees for carry-ons and checked baggage.  We understand these struggles all to well, we were that family!  As a result of this, we decided to launch Coast 2 Coast Babies , the perfect solution for this problem.  Mom! Dad!  You can tuck away your troubles.

 

 

Let Coast 2 Coast Babies do all of the work for you and have everything waiting at your vacation home, resort, hotel, airport, car rental location or even the family home when you arrive. You RENT Baby Equipment & we DELIVER directly to your doorstep. You will never again travel with your infants or toddlers any other way.

 

 

 

 

 Our baby gear is safety checked, thoroughly cleaned and sanitized before each use which ensures a safe and comforting experience. You can have peace of mind knowing that your little ones safety and comfort is our number one priority because of the care and attention to detail that we put into the maintenance of our equipment.  

 

 

We carry a large inventory of baby equipment which includes Cribs, Strollers, Joggers, Car Seats, High Chairs, Pack-n-Plays, Health/Safety items, Toys, and much more.   Visit our website www.coast2coastbabies.com to view the full line of products that we carry and to place your order today!

 

What We Need

We need your help to take Coast 2 Coast Babies  Nationwide.  The funds that are raised by this campaign will go towards purchasing inventory to support our expansion, running a national advertising campaign,  staffing of our offices and delivery drivers, system upgrades to handle the increase in traffic, and developing an app. 

The app will  allow the traveler to have at their finger tips the ability to make reservations, process payments, and track deliveries. It also gives us the ability to expand our delivery coverage areas by employing more drivers.

 

 

The Rewards 

These are exciting times for us at Coast 2 Coast Babies  by us having the opportunity to go nationwide with our service.  The opportunity to have you as our Backer for this campaign and as a customer adds to our excitement!  We want you to share in this.  This has lead us to put together some amazing Perks to show our gratitude.  Our perks range from a heart felt Thank You card to Free Orders.  You also receive our commitment to providing you with outstanding customer service from the time the order is placed to the delivery and pickup of the equipment.

OUR PERKS

 

The Impact

We have serviced over twenty thousand  customers traveling to Southern California on vacation, business or visiting family.  By contributing to Coast 2 Coast Babies  you will make it possible for us to take this extraordinary service nationwide!   With our proven track record we are more than prepared for the task at hand.  If you are a repeat customer or a first time customer you will appreciate having a choice of not having the worries of packing and lugging strollers, car seats, pack n plays and other items with you on your trip. 

 

 

With our expansion you will now be able to enjoy this luxury in cities across the Nation!  Not only will you relieve a great amount of stress from your travel, you will also relieve the damage to your equipment caused by careless baggage handlers.  We all know how expensive Baby Equipment  can be!  

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't afford to make a contribution don't worry - you can still help by spreading the word about this fundraising campaign! Please share our links on Twitter, Facebook and other social media platforms, and encourage your family and friends to contribute.  Here are the Coast 2 Coast Babies links to share: 

If you have Twitter, please retweet our announcement tweet to help spread the word!

Thank you so much for reading, and thank you especially for your support! You can make a huge difference by Backing Coast 2 Coast Babies  today!
